175934865,"Abstract Comorbidity of bipolar disorder (BD) with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is frequent. The management of comorbid ADHD and BD is complicated by the risk of induction of (hypo) mania by the medications used for ADHD treatment. Earlier reports in children and adolescents with ADHD-BD suggest that the possibility of (hypo) mania induction is low when atomoxetine is used along mood stabilizers or antipsychotics. Here, we report induction of hypomania by atomoxetine when used for the treatment of comorbid ADHD in a BD patient while on prophylactic treatment with mood stabilizers. This report indicates that atomoxetine carries the risk of induction of (hypo) mania even in stabilized BD patients. Clinicians should closely monitor such patients for (hypo) mania symptoms. Keywords: Atomoxetine , attention deficit hyperactivity disorder , bipolar disorder , hypomania , mania Go to: INTRODUCTION Bipolar disorder (BD) is an episodic mood disorder and has a significant psychiatric comor
bidity.[1] Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) persists in adulthood in about two-third of patients, affecting 2.5‚Äì4.4% of adults.[2] Concomitant BD and ADHD are frequent with 10‚Äì21% of adults with BD having ADHD and 5‚Äì20% of adults with ADHD having BD.[2,3] Subjects with comorbid ADHD and BD have poorer outcomes, and the management is further complicated by the risk of induction of (hypo) mania with the medications used for ADHD treatment.[2,4] Here we report induction of hypomania by atomoxetine, a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor when used for the treatment of comorbid ADHD in a patient with BD. Go to: CASE REPORT Mr. A, a 22-year-old male, with diagnosis of BD (age of onset 20 years) and borderline personality disorder (BPD) was stable on sodium valproate 1000 mg/day and quetiapine 400 mg/day since a year. He was adherent with medications and had adequate serum valproate levels (95 ¬µg/ml). He then had an impulsive deliberate self-harm attempt following a stressor and was admi
tted for in-patient care. During the in-patient evaluation, he reported significant inattention since childhood (age of onset 6‚Äì7 years). On further exploration, he was found to have features suggestive of impulsivity and hyperactivity, causing significant impairment in his academic and interpersonal functioning. On structured evaluation, he fulfilled the DSM-5 criteria for adult ADHD and scored 24 on the conners‚Äô adult ADHD rating scale. We educated the patient and his caregivers about ADHD, and added tablet atomoxetine 18 mg/day to his treatment regimen and increased it to 25 mg/day after 5 days (0.4 mg/kg body weight). After the 2nd day of receiving 25 mg/day of atomoxetine, he was noted to be more talkative than usual and irritable over minor issues. From the following day, he started reporting expansive ideas and appeared overfamiliar with treating team members. His need for sleep decreased and psychomotor activity increased. On rating with Young‚Äôs Mania Rating Scale, he scored 14. These symptoms w
ere consistently noted for about 3 days while he was on atomoxetine 25 mg/day. After discussing with the patient and his family, atomoxetine was stopped and other medications were continued at the same dose. Hypomanic symptoms resolved over next 4‚Äì5 days and he became euthymic. The patient also had family history of BD in a second-degree relative and history of manic switch with imipramine. The score on the _PERSON_ adverse drug reaction probability was 8, suggesting that atomoxetine-induced hypomania was probable. Go to: DISCUSSION There are no randomized controlled trials that have evaluated any treatment in adult patients with ADHD-BD, and no definitive treatment recommendations are available.[5] The consensus is to follow staged or hierarchical approach by treating BD first and then treat ADHD.[2,6] It is believed that mood stabilizers provide protection against the possible risk of (hypo) mania induction with the medications used for ADHD.[2,7] In the above scenario, our patient was euthymic and on ade
quate doses of two mood stabilizers when we commenced pharmacotherapy for ADHD. Several experts suggest avoiding these medications in BD patients, especially in those having risk factors such as family history of psychosis or BD.[8,9,10] However, earlier reports in children and adolescents with ADHD-BD suggest that the possibility of (hypo) manic switch is low when atomoxetine is used along with mood stabilizers or antipsychotics.[11] In the patient described above, as the dose of atomoxetine was increased, we witnessed hypomanic symptoms. These hypomanic symptoms disappeared within few days of stopping atomoxetine. To our knowledge, this is the second report of atomoxetine-induced mania/hypomania in an adult patient. The first report was published in 1985, in a 46-year-old patient with major depressive disorder having family history of postpartum depression.[12] An important point in this report is that the hypomania occurred while the patient was on treatment with two mood stabilizers at adequate doses. Thi
s is probably the first report of atomoxetine-induced hypomania in an adult patient stabilized on mood stabilizers. Conversely, the literature on children and adolescents with ADHD has several documented reports of atomoxetine-induced (hypo) mania.[13,14,15,16,17,18] In an uncontrolled open trial, about one-third (33%) of ADHD children receiving atomoxetine reported irritability, hypomania, mania, and aggression. In this study, the majority of the affected children experiencing above-mentioned adverse effects had family or history suggestive of mood disorder or symptoms.[13] The salient features of published case reports on atomoxetine-induced (hypo) mania in children and adolescents are summarized in Table 1.[14,15,16,17,18] A family history of affective disorder was commonly seen in these case reports, similar to the findings from the trial described above.[13] In addition, the findings from these case reports suggest atomoxetine-induced hypo (mania) to be a dose-dependent phenomenon with a higher probabili
ty at the dose range of least 0.8‚Äì1.7 mg/kg of body weight. The patient, in this case, developed hypomania at a dose of 0.4 mg/kg. However, it is to be noted that he was a known case of BD. The dose of atomoxetine required to induce hypo (mania) in adults with BD and the role of comorbid conditions such as BPD need further investigation. Table 1 Summary of published reports on atomoxetine induced (hypo) mania in children and adolescents with ADHD An external file that holds a picture, illustration, etc. Object name is IJPsyM-39-89-g001.jpg1010√ó317 87.4 KB Go to: CONCLUSION Atomoxetine carries the risk of induction of (hypo) mania even in stabilized patients with BD. Clinicians should closely monitor such patients for (hypo) manic symptoms. Further systematic research is required on the predictors and pathophysiology of atomoxetine-induced hypo (mania) in children and adults. PubMed Central (PMC) Atomoxetine Induced Hypomania in a Patient with Bipolar Disorder and Adult... Comorbidity of bipolar disorder (B
D) with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is frequent. The management of comorbid ADHD and BD is complicated by the risk of induction of (hypo) mania by the medications used for ADHD treatment. Earlier..."

174336596,"ncbi.nlm.nih.gov Evolution of Religious Topics in Schizophrenia in 80 Years Period. A Dudek, M Krzystanek, _PERSON_ and A G√≥rna, Psychiatria Danubina , Sep 2019 Environment and culture are shown to be an important factor influencing characteristics of psychotic symptoms. Content of hallucinations and delusions is a projection of internal processes on external world. Religion plays a central role to lives of many people, but in schizophrenia religious experience and spirituality is confounded by psychotic symptoms. The aim of this study was to find how content of hallucinations and delusions interact with cultural conditions, that were changing over the decades.100 of case histories from 2012 were randomly selected. From the medical record, content of hallucinations and delusion was extracted and categorized. Data from 2012 was compared with previous study by the authors, obtaining perspective of 80 years of history in the one hospital.Religious content of delusions and hallucinations appeared in 2
6% of patients. Diversity of the religious and spiritual themes in schizophrenia has been gradually decreasing. Many minor religious entities and figures such as ""saints"" and ""angels"" disappeared in 2012. Although, occurrence of contact with God and other religious figures was similar as in previous years, number of ""visions"" abruptly decreased. All of the religious content was culture-specific.Religious topics express general plasticity over a time, following cultural changes in society."

175935257,"_AT_MENTION_ I was in charge of hiring and managing a team of people at my last job. I really valued people who were able to be flexible, because I could trust them to get the work done by the deadline. Because they were working on their own schedule, they felt less stressed and produced better results. Some of them preferred to take most of their work home to do late at night, some people preferred to work during normal business hours. As long as they got all their tasks completed and produced high quality work, I had no problem with them taking breaks/logging hours whenever they wanted. This is obviously not appropriate for every environment, but for my team, it was awesome. Unfortunately, some managers go by what they can see, not by results. If they see employees taking breaks and goofing around, they scold them for not using time wisely. In reality, taking breaks helps keep people from getting burnt out and leads to longer employee retention and fewer sick days."

175935361,"I am not bipolar, but my 31 yo son is. I am trying to support him emotionally and sometimes financially through this, even though I, too, am stressed and having trouble (including sleeping). I urge you to find a voluntary therapist online for one-on-one counseling through this. I just got myself one of these sessions and it felt so good to get out of my head for the hour, hear both emotionally supportive words but also very practical advice that I immediately gave to my son. I'm worried about him every day. But I'm also worried about smothering him with resources and advice. I asked him if it was too much, and he said it wasn't. That I wasn't upsetting him. So, friends, reach out. No matter what. A 3 hour time difference is not insurmountable. Connect. Force yourselves to. And also, cut yourselves some slack. Focus on feeling better and not feeling the deficits of what you can't do right now. So brush your teeth at noon. Who cares? But do try something every day that connects you to friends, family
, mental health professionals, and nature. Take care."
175935362,"I took 2.5 mg last night of buspar. 5mg this morning. And getting ready to take the nighttime dose. I don't, just yet have an opinion, I'm really tired today. Not sure if it's related to regular old exhaustion or if the buspar made me more tired. Although, if I woke up one day feeling good, energized, no achy joints and not tired, I would assume I was dead. I would definitely think... I feel too good, something must be wrong. Lol I kept trying to stop myself during my day, at work, to focus on how my brain felt. Did I feel anxiety, was my brain thinking of 20 random things at the same time, was agitated at all... Can't say I was. I tried to make my brain speed up and start going in circles and I couldn't. I couldn't self induce anxiety. Now, of course, was it the buspar, was it just being too tired to care, was it a placebo effect bc I consciously knew that buspar should be calming my brain? Idk and only time will tell. 174336678,"https://healthitanalytics.com/news/new-imaging-analytics-method-may-boost-schizophrenia-treatment July 01, 2020 - An innovative imaging analytics method helped researchers categorize subgroups of schizophrenia patients using functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) data, according to a study published in NeuroImage .The technique could enable researchers to identify key patterns in brain imaging for those with mental illness, and assist in the diagnosis and treatment of patients with mental illnesses that are difficult to identify. Additionally, the method could show medical practitioners whether the current treatments have or have not been working based on image groupings.Diagnosing and treating mental illness is an incredibly complex process, researchers noted. The same illness can present differently across patients, and there is usually no singular treatment that will be effective for all patients. Once a treatment is in place, its success can also vary from patient to patient."

174336673,"ncbi.nlm.nih.gov Change in smoking cessation stage over 1?year in patients with schizophrenia: a follow up study in Japan. _PERSON_, _PERSON_, _PERSON_, _PERSON_, _PERSON_, _PERSON_ So, I _PERSON_, _PERSON_, _PERSON_, _PERSON_, _PERSON_, _PERSON_, _PERSON_, _PERSON_, _PERSON_ and _PERSON_, BMC psychiatry , Nov 21 2019 We performed a follow up study about willingness and behaviors to quit smoking among smokers with schizophrenia in Japan.Participants were outpatients with schizophrenia aged 20-69?years who had been visiting the hospital for ?1?year as of April 1, 2016, and had visited the hospital more than once in the previous 6?months. A baseline survey on smoking behaviors including current smoking status and smoking cessation stage, was administered in 420 participants that were randomly extracted from a patient pool (n?=?680) in 2016, and a follow-up survey was administered in 2017. We calculated the distribution and change in smoking cessation stage, number of smokers and nonsmokers after 1?ye
ar, and quitting rate from a naturalistic 1-year smoking-cessation follow up.The number of baseline respondents was 350; 113 current smokers and 68 former smokers. Among the 113 current smokers, 104 (92.0%) were followed for 1?year, 79 (70.0%) were interested in smoking cessation, and only 7 had received smoking cessation treatments at baseline. Among the tracked 104 participants, only 6 (5.8%) stopped smoking after 1?year. Among the 25 participants who had intentions to quit smoking within 6?months at baseline, 6 (24.0%) maintained their intention to quit smoking for 1?year, and 16 (64.0%) did not maintain their intention to quit smoking.Our findings showed that many smokers with schizophrenia were interested in quitting smoking, but few patients received treatment and actually quit smoking. Timely intervention, including the option to receive smoking cessation treatment, is necessary for those patients with schizophrenia who smoke.UMIN Clinical Trials Registry (UMIN_PHONE_NO_, registered on August 31, 2016)

175935512,"Tried both of them and personally prefer loxapine over olanzapine for a few reasons. First, loxapine works much better, especially when you go through the pains of taking it four times a day (I take 5 mg four times a day). Also, loxapine kills my paranoia and my psychosis altogether whereas olanzapine leaves me paranoid. The icing on the cake is no weight gain which I like a lot. Patients with schizophrenia may show dysfunctional impulsivity and impulsive aggression. 175935548,"To speak of illusion, hallucination simulation and so on is to commit to something real in light of which these experiences are illusory and so on. 175935550,"Kinda long first (maybe?) post, dont remember. Hey there, i'm from the lyme forum,so not new to Healing Well(lots of posts), but seem to be cured of lyme after many years. That messes up your entire body. Many lymies have anx and dep which get better as the lyme gets better. You really end up learning way more about the entire body than you ever thought possible. It also causes autoimmune issues in some people (myself), so complete healthfullness might never be a part of ones life again. As a specialized ex pro level athlete in the past (I worked my way up and is wasn't a team sport, so not rich or famous !..LOL), this was/is especially hard on me and changed my future forever. But I am alive and can do some things (and recover) that I could not do without pain for quite sometime. Life is now, currently better and for the most part, worth getting out of bed........it wasnt before when ill for years. Now in my early 50's, I have already out lived some people in my life, so, yea, being above ground i
s good, but still not easy to deal with. Lingering autoimmune issues does still have an affect on my life and job choices, but less than the near past. That said, autoimmune seldom gets better...thus the name of it. Its managed at best. BUT.....This co$t a lot of time and money and of course, some life dreams. So I'm trying to make up for it and getting burned out in the process. I had to put many things off, never got a good career (many dont anymore anyway), home repairs added up ect. I have a hi-tech ""job"" and then I have self side job on the side which I like but have little time for. I try to live as simple as possible with a simple home / basic purchases, basic cars ect. but life and work still stress me out and I get more anxiety. I had no anxiety as a kid, I want that feeling again but feel its impossible as an adult with responsibilities like work and cost of living. When I competed, I was a vary fine tuned machine that could put everything aside and hone in on the prize, but thats what all good at
hletes can do. When not competing, most are regular people, human. My remaining anxiety comes down to To many bills, (and repair $urprizes), not enough time, and still some mysterious health issues. Health anxiety is hard to not think about . It comes down to stress. I feel like I stress over things I shouldn't- that are part of adult life. I seem to need more ""time out"" than most people, being introverted is part of that too. Probably not to rare (?). But if this is common, we as a society are not doing so well. I think my brain chemicals are pretty well balanced vs when it was out of wack from lyme. I did try...Zoloft? back then..made me a boring emotionaless zombie, my sense of humor was gone and I was not any better, prob cause of the lyme. Im pretty well versed in adrenal support health and adapogenic herbs that can make stress easier, but this seems never ending. If I won the lottery, I would live a simple life with work freedom, vs these people who spend it all and go to jail or die from all the part
yinging and huge purchases. . A year off of everything is prob what the Dr would order, but thats not possible. Taking a regular under two week vacation fixes nothing, as you come back home and go back to the daily grind. I know some people just sell everything and start over- but thats just taking a chance, not really a good one either.....seems like that is the same as running away. I like and aim for stability. Ive know people that dont do well with societies/lifes pressures, they dont fit in to well and either deal with it by alcohol or pot. Some drunks Ive known are now dead, and the stoners I knew, well, some are still stoned all the time, the others cleaned up there act 100%. Purposely ""Bluring"" reality is not a permanent solution for me, not going there, thats not how I do things. Guess if this site had a stress forum I'd post it there. Notice I didnt ask any direct questions on how to fix this, as I bet some here are worse, but yea, Id like to fix this for good. Ran out of ideas. So Im open to hear

174336717,"ncbi.nlm.nih.gov Sex hormone levels in drug-na√Øve, first-episode patients with psychosis. _PERSON_, _PERSON_, AT _PERSON_, A _PERSON_, I _PERSON_ and _PERSON_, International journal of psychiatry in clinical practice , Dec 2019 11 Aim: Sex differences have long been reported in schizophrenia leading to the hypothesis that sex hormones may be implicated in the pathophysiology of the disorder. We assessed gonadal hormones during the fasted state in drug-na√Øve patients with psychosis.Method: Fasting serum concentrations of follicular-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH), testosterone, free-testosterone, Sex Hormone Binding Globulin (SHBG) and oestradiol (E2) were compared between a group of 55 newly diagnosed, drug-na√Øve, first-episode men with psychosis and a group of 55 healthy controls, matched for age, smoking status and BMI. Testosterone, free-testosterone and SHBG were compared between a group of 32 drug-na√Øve, first-episode females with psychosis and a group of 32 healthy 
controls matched for age, smoking status and BMI.Results: Testosterone and free-testosterone levels were significantly lower in the patients' group and SHBG levels significantly higher in the patients' group compared to those in healthy controls. The two female groups had similar values in the hormones which were measured.Conclusion: Our findings provide evidence of lower testosterone and free-testosterone levels and increased SHBG levels in drug-na√Øve, first-episode males with psychosis.KEY POINTSReduced testosterone and free-testosterone levels in drug-naive, first-episode males with psychosis.Increased SHBG levels in drug-naive first-episode males with psychosis.No difference in FSH, LH and E2 levels between drug-naive first episode males with psychosis and controls.No difference in testosterone, free-testosterone and SHBG levels between drug-naive, first-episode women with psychosis and controls."
175935595,"I‚Äôm a buzzkill here but I love sugar in my tea. Also love my carbs. My blood sugar is stable because I avoid fat. My tea uses skim milk. What causes high blood sugar isn‚Äôt so much the carbs as it is the saturated fat intake. The saturated fat blocks the glucose uptake pathways in the muscles and forms ‚Äúintermyocellular lipids‚Äù (intramuscular fat.) The more of that there is, the more insulin you will need to express to get the glucose past that. It‚Äôs the main cause of diet-related diabetes. Without that fat you could consume a lot of fat-free carbs and have a balanced blood sugar level. So, avoid saturated fat and avoid diabetes, effectively. The Dr. _PERSON_ diet is predicated on this. It can actually heal diabetes as well since the pancreas is given a chance to heal due to underutilization. But if you‚Äôre adamant on eating high fat meals then you‚Äôll need to cut sugar and carbs to balance blood sugar."

175935661,"My first and absolute rule when it comes to that is: ""never ever have children ever"". So... yeah, I can't contribute much on that. I think _PERSON_ got a lot of it decently covered though. I really agree from personal experience with this part in particular: It depends on how tired and irritable I am (which depends in large part on how well I've been sleeping, which in turn depends in large part on how stressed I've been lately, so it's a feedback loop). Sometimes, simply not being demanded any action or response by the people around me is enough. That's rare though. Usually, even the simple awareness of an appointment in the near future can be enough to ""break the immersion"". I hate having any pending things whatsoever to deal with that I can't just get over with as soon as I'm reminded of them. So I try to minimize those periods when I'll be aware of time-sensitive things that I can't get over with right away. It's better to squeeze as many of those time-sensitive things into a tiring but sho
rt period than to give myself weeks to be bothered by each of them. I instinctively tend to get more unrelated chores done that don't have a set timing the closer it gets to those time-specific things. That's good on one hand, but it can also easily drain me too much to deal with the time-specific thing that's been bothering me, which is really bad if I end up having to postpone it. So I try to be careful with that. When it comes to recurring things that aren't exactly time-specific but are still time-sensitive (like, say, grocery shopping), I try to turn them into consistent habits so they're moved from the ""conscious worry"" area of my mind to the ""automatic fact of life"" area. ""It's Tuesday, therefore XYZ"". I don't need to think about it, I just know it. One of the things that this applies to is my regular ""social interaction"" (namely: visiting my parents). My daily levels of stress have improved dramatically with these consistent habits since I moved to my current place a couple years ago. Rereadin
g what I said above, most of it doesn't really seem related to ""being alone"" at first glance, but I guess my sense of being alone really is tied to a sense of not having to worry about forcing thoughts and considerations into or out of my very limited mental focus. This is the point where I think SPD and ADHD can overlap quite a bit. I guess part of the above applies here. I guess part of the above applies again. Consistent, well-defined and clearly-stated habits and expectations (and consistent, well-defined and clearly-stated ways to introduce exceptions or change habits and expectations when necessary)."

175935688,"I could see that. I don‚Äôt really mind the word recovery myself but there are times that I feel like I‚Äôm supposed to get back an old self, which is impossible. There‚Äôs this excerpt that I really like, which I thought of when you mentioned being better than before: ""During my survivor personality research I became aware of a big gap in survivor stories. I found stories about people being made stronger and better from every kind of human adversity except for people who have gone through a mental or emotional disturbance. The silence about such survivors is especially puzzling considering a statement made by the famous psychiatrist _NAME_ in 1963: Not infrequently we observe that a patient who is in a phase of recovery from what may have been a rather long illness shows continued improvement, past the point of his former ‚Äònormal‚Äô state of existence. He not only gets well, to use the vernacular; he gets as well as he was, and then continues to improve still further. He increases his productiv
ity, he expands his life and its horizons. He develops new talents, new powers, new effectiveness. He becomes, one might say, ‚Äúweller than well.‚Äù‚Ä¶every experienced psychiatrist has seen it‚Ä¶What could it mean? It violates our conventional medical expectations, so perhaps it is often overlooked and occurs more often than we know. It may contain a clue for better prevention and better treatment. (p.406) ‚Ä¶transcendence does occur. And perhaps it is not an exception but a natural consequence of new insights and new concepts of treatment‚Ä¶Transcendence might happen oftener if we could more frankly acknowledge the possibility of its occurrence, expect it, hope for it, even though we are bound to be often disappointed‚Ä¶the reader can be certain that there are thousands of unknown examples who have not been discovered or who have not yet written about their experiences. (p. 409)"" The Vital Balance The Viking Press, 1963 Co-authors _NAME_ and _NAME_"

175935717,"It appears that I have hit a wall in my spiritual and emotional wellness; something that is quite abstruse to me individually. At times, I feel a earning for a restitution of things as they once were, graceful and grotesque times both. Unequivocally, though, that restoration is not to take place because of my mental illnesses, which has rendered me to a place of desolate solitude, unable to climb up from the deep pit of despair. However nominal I feel like this moment will become in the future, it is imperative that I answer this question, what is there more to do to become a person who is liked and recieved favorably? I have intentionally avoided this question for the space of many years, even before schizophrenia. Why do I feel such a solemnity for this question? The answer I have tried to reach and hold for a duration of time has been gone from my sight. Previously, I thought that I was well-liked, but now that period of my book of life seems more and more distant. Though I sincerely try to be a
ltruistic and charitable to people, I often feel like that same positive emotion is not resent. I do wonder a lot, as I suppose a lot of introspective people do, what is there to do to become the person we are destined, or rather directed to be. But this question is of complete futility, because I know that I cannot answer it on my own. For instance, I set up a monthly donation to _USER_ID_ for the foreseeable future, to try to help people learn more about mental illness. But I feel this is not enough, and I‚Äôm not sure if it accounts for all of my transgressions to people and myself. I guess this is the age old question of wondering what is enough to truly repent, which in my definition, means change. Sorry for this being real long, but I wanted to improve upon my writing voice, so this is essentially practice but it is also candid and sincere. I feel like this is the one thing I can actually be mediocre at, so I wanted to improve. And this is the only way I know how, plus I‚Äôm not very good at fiction or 
poetry."

175935737,"en.wikipedia.org Ironic process theory Ironic process theory, ironic rebound, or the white bear problem refers to the psychological process whereby deliberate attempts to suppress certain thoughts make them more likely to surface. An example is how when someone is actively trying not to think of a white bear they may actually be more likely to imagine one. ""Try to pose for yourself this task: not to think of a polar bear, and you will see that the cursed thing will come to mind every minute."" ‚Äî _PERSON_, Winter Notes on Sum... Look there^ Somewhere along the way you‚Äôve been spooked (probably by synchronicity ((look here -->)) https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Synchronicity and the knowledge that Telepathy isn‚Äôt just a Star Trek thing) This has made you much more concerned with your thinking processes The brain is sort of like a computer we can accidentally hack. If I believe I have an open connection, and fear that connection may be compromised, I‚Äôd be apt to listen for and try and hold back 
anything coming to mind that may have been interjected by a nemesis. This causes stress on the mind and the mind will release that stress by forcing up whatever you‚Äôre trying to force down. While some synchromatic experiences may be genuine most, if not all, are accidental and non-targeted; but, as with Tourettes syndrome, we end up playing a game with ourselves accidentally and hacking our mind into a looping no-win process."

As a result, some of the public stigmatize the mentally ill and believe that the mentally ill should be shunned, locked away in mental institutions, heavily medicated, or a combination of the three. 175935841,"IDK. Do they want you to move out? Do you want to move out? Do bears sh*t in the woods? Wait a minute, I digress. I lived in group homes. Living in those homes takes the pressure off of living with parents or roommates or by yourself. And if you get in the right one, you have few responsibilities‚Ä¶ That can be both good and bad. When I lived in one from 1990-95 It was a pretty simple way to live. I don‚Äôt know about your country and how the group homes are or even if you have them or if they are roughly the same as American ones. But the one I was in, the owners were a husband and wife. They hired a cleaning lady to come in on weekends and help the wife clean. They also did all the shopping and cooking and everybody in the house ate together. That was the only time we had to be all together, otherwise the rest of the time you could pretty much do what you want. Some people just stayed at home hanging out smoking or drinking soda. Others had some kind of daytime activity but it wasn‚Äôt required. 
I shared a room with one other guy, we had room for a few possessions and we just had to make our beds each morning and keep our few possessions neat. We didn‚Äôt have to do any cleaning though we did our own laundry on the premises on weekends. Violence was not tolerated. Supposedly either were drugs or drinking but I know some people were doing those. We could come and go as we please as long as we were home for meals but there was a curfew at night of 10:00 pm. It was flexible though because I was going to AA meetings almost every night and sometimes I got home after 10:00 pm but it was for a good reason so they allowed it. People had their own radios and even TV‚Äôs but the only entertainment the home provided was a TV with a VCR and a cabinet of some of the coolest movies on video. It was all guys so the owner had movies like Rambo, Dirty _NAME_, Total Recall, Top Gun, Predator etc. Idk, I lived there 5 years but the time passed quickly. I only made one friend the whole time but I wasn‚Äôt hated. I happe
n to be working and going to school and that meant I wasn‚Äôt part of the crowd who hung out together but they didn‚Äôt hassle me, they just let me alone and I let them alone. It‚Äôs cool, I can handle being a loner sometimes. The whole thing was OK, it wasn‚Äôt a bad experience. Oh yeah, the owners kept everybody‚Äôs medication and handed them out at 7:00 pm every night."

174336800,"This sounds similar to my experience. When I got ill with psychosis, I had insight in the beginning. As it got worse, over a period of 6 months, I gradually lost the ability to distinguish reality from my mind, as the new way of thinking took over. Years later I asked my psychiatrist about my insight, and she said it was common for people to question their experiences before the illness fully manifests itself. PTSD can definitely cause psychosis. Some people, who are chronically stressed, can become psychotic. It doesn't automatically mean a diagnosis of schizophrenia. Sometimes getting the right diagnosis takes time. - My illness lasted about 16 months. I don't have schizophrenia. It was just called first episode psychosis."

175936261,"It's right, but it's partial. Others' pov is limited too. If you exchange the roles, would you say that you understand and know others better than they do? We all don't know the history of a person, the context where her ideas and way of being are born; we can see her mask and her appearance, probably better than she does, but we could mistake her mask for her real personality. We can't see her ‚Äúfrom inside‚Äù, as she does, or we can do it partially. We are less focused on others than they are, then our observation and memory, in their regard, are likely to be more superficial. Furthermore, confirmation bias is affecting our judgment of other people too. As we all are inter-related, how we perceive others has a consequence on our own self-image. It's schematic, however... less or more, ‚Äúnarcissists‚Äù need to underestimate people, ‚Äúthose who play the victim‚Äù need an evil person, ‚Äúthose who play the evil person‚Äù need a victim or a stupid person, ‚Äúinsecure people‚Äù need someone strong 
and able to protect them, and so on. We need to imagine others to be in a certain way, to strengthen our self-image and continue the ‚Äúsocial dance‚Äù. Finally, we can't have an entirely objective vision of ourselves, but others can lack objectivity or understanding too. That's why we need to listen to others, and consider their opinion, but it's a big mistake to exclude our own self-knowledge. Surely, if many people send us the same message, it's more likely to be true, but it could still be directed to our social mask. I think that there isn't a definitive answer. Disinterested observation would be the key, but we can often fail in it."

175936343,"MDPI Beyond Dopamine Receptor Antagonism: New Targets for Schizophrenia Treatment... Treatment of schizophrenia (SCZ) historically relies on the use of antipsychotic drugs to treat psychosis, with all of the currently available antipsychotics acting through the antagonism of dopamine D2 receptors. Although antipsychotics reduce... A very dense and long article but a good overview of how several of the medications in trial might normalize _USER_ID_ transmission and hippocampal hyperactivity. aberrant dopamine transmission and associated SCZ symptoms have been proposed as a consequence of disruption in afferent brain regions that regulate the dopamine system, mainly cortical and hippocampal regions. Hence, treatment at the site of pathology could be a more effective therapeutic avenue than current antipsychotics that target D2 receptors. For example, in the hippocampus a functional loss of PV interneurons has been associated with hippocampal hyperactivity that is proposed to underlie the hyperdopamin
ergic state observed in SCZ [54,55]. A hyperactive hippocampus can also interfere with the function of other circuits leading to cognitive deficits and negatives symptoms (Figure 1). Thus, targeting excitatory‚Äìinhibitory balance may alleviate positive, negative, and cognitive symptoms of SCZ [54]. Therefore, one potential approach for treating a broad range of SCZ symptoms is to modulate abnormalities in glutamate and GABA neurotransmission, as will be discussed below. A further approach that could potentially normalize the functional loss of PV interneurons would be the modulation of Kv3.1 potassium channels on these cells. The Kv3.1 channel is part of the family of Kv3-type voltage-gated potassium channels (Kv3.1-Kv3.4) that have fast-spiking properties [74]. Kv3.1 channels are abundantly expressed in PV interneurons and play an important role in regulating their activity by allowing these cells to fire at high frequency and, thus, enabling the synchronized activity of pyramidal neurons and generation of 
gamma oscillations [75,76], which is dramatically impaired in SCZ [53]. Therefore, the modulation of these channels could potentially normalize the impaired activity of these interneurons in SCZ Another approach that could compensate for decreases in PV interneuron functionality is to increase GABA neurotransmission. One target that has shown some promise is the GABAA receptor containing the ?5 subtype (?5-GABAA) [81], which is highly expressed in limbic brain regions, mainly in the hippocampus and to a lesser extent in the neocortex [82,83,84]. A proposed function of ?5-GABAA receptors is the _USER_ID_ regulation of inhibitory inputs to pyramidal neurons, coordinating spike timing of these neurons and balancing excitation [85,86,87]. Of particular interest is the involvement of the ?5-GABAA receptor present on pyramidal neurons regulating GABA inputs arising from perisomatic targeting PV-expressing interneurons (Figure 2). Preclinical studies have supported the potential use of ?5-GABAA receptors positive al
losteric modulator (PAM) to treat SCZ. Several mechanisms have been proposed to explain how agonists of mAChR M4 could counteract a hyperdopaminergic state. The activation of mAChR M4 on cholinergic interneurons in the striatum reduces local cholinergic tone within the striatum, which reduces striatal dopamine levels [122,123]. Similar outcomes were found by Foster and colleagues, where the activation of mAChR M4 receptors on D1 receptor-spiny projection neurons may increase the release of the endocannabinoid 2-arachidonoylglycerol that, through the activation of cannabinoid CB2 receptors located in presynaptic terminals of dopamine neurons, leads to sustained inhibition of dopamine release [124]. In addition, the activation of presynaptic mAChR M4 located in laterodorsal tegmental nuclei cholinergic neurons projecting to the VTA reduces local cholinergic tone, which may modulate dopamine neuron activity. Trace amine-associated receptor 1 (TAAR1) is a G-protein-coupled receptor activated by endogenous trace a
mines that are structurally related to monoaminergic neurotransmitters. The expression of TAAR1 was reported in several brain regions, such as the prefrontal cortex, striatum, _USER_ID_, nucleus accumbens, and ventral tegmental area [125]. It is proposed that the activation of TAAR1 modulates presynaptic dopamine synthesis capacity [126], which may produce antipsychotic-like effects. Moreover, TAAR1 may alter D2 receptor-mediated signaling through the formation of heterodimers [127]. In mice, SEP-363856, a TAAR1 agonist developed by Sunovion Pharmaceuticals, reduced dopamine synthesis capacity induced by repeated treatment with ketamine [128]. SEP-363856 was also found to inhibit neuronal firing and decrease excitability in the ventral tegmental area [129]. In addition to TAAR1, SEP-363856 also acts as a 5-HT1A receptor agonist [129]. Recent clinical trials have evaluated SEP-363856 for SCZ. In a phase-II, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled 4-week, SEP-363856 was superior to placebo for reducing bot
h positive and negative symptoms of SCZ without inducing side effects of current antipsychotics [130]. Phase 3 clinical trials are ongoing. Clinical trials investigating the effects of ralmitaront (RO6889450), a TAAR1 partial agonist, in SCZ are also ongoing. They also suggest NAC and suforaphane as preventative treatments."

174336912,"GEN - Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology News ‚Äì 3 May 19 Epigenetic Hotspot for Schizophrenia and Bipolar Disorder Identified Scientists at the _NAME_ Andel Research Institute (VARI) believe that a newly-identified epigenetic hotspot for schizophrenia and bipolar disorder may give scientists a fresh path forward for devising more effective treatments and biomarker-based... This seems like a major breakthrough, even though I‚Äôm sure it‚Äôll still require 15-20 years of study before we get something that helps people. Scientists at the _NAME_ Andel Research Institute (VARI) believe that a newly-identified epigenetic hotspot for schizophrenia and bipolar disorder may give scientists a fresh path forward for devising more effective treatments and biomarker-based screening strategies. _PERSON_ and her collaborators found a cluster of epigenetic marks that ratchets up dopamine production while simultaneously scrambling the brain‚Äôs synapses. The result is a major shake-up of the brain‚Äôs organiza
tion and chemical balance that fuels symptoms of psychosis. ‚ÄúWhat we‚Äôre seeing is a one-two punch‚Äîthe brain is being flooded with too much dopamine and at the same time it is losing these critical neural connections,‚Äù _PERSON_ said. ‚ÄúLike many other neurological disorders, schizophrenia and bipolar disorder often have early, or prodromal, phases that begin years before obvious symptoms. It is our hope that our findings may lead to new biomarkers to screen for risk, which would then allow for earlier intervention.‚Äù The team took a comprehensive look at DNA derived from brain cells of people with either schizophrenia or bipolar disorder and compared them to healthy controls. Their analyses revealed a cluster of epigenetic marks, which switch genes on and off, in an enhancer at a gene called IGF2, a critical regulator of synaptic development. Enhancers are stretches of DNA that help activate genes and can be major players in the development of diseases in the brain and other tissues. This enhancer al
so controls the activity of the nearby called tyrosine hydroxylase gene, which keeps dopamine in check. When the enhancer is epigenetically switched on, production of dopamine becomes dysregulated, resulting in too much of the chemical in the brain. Taken together, molecular changes at this site may explain why psychosis brought on by dopamine frequently is accompanied by a disruption of brain synapses, a devastating double-hit that promotes symptoms."

174336935,"I agree but the fact that they suppress their feelings so guardedly would suggest that even when their most powerful emotions rise to the surface, they're still tempered by that fear of exposing them. Sometimes I look at my strongest emotions like wild animals that must be kept caged and sedated or else they will run amok. People who are generally outwardly over emotional are the ones who are most likely to commit crimes of passion. Schizoids are more likely to keep theirs under lock and key. Maybe they filter them through introspection: I really want to stab this bitch in the face but if I do there will be some bad consequences that I don't care to deal with. My comment about some schizoids being stupid was poorly a rendered illustration of my point. There's bound to be a percentage of any group that's just stupid. I don't think being intelligent predisposes one to developing SPD. Still, suppressing emotions, even when it's advantageous is more or a defense mechanism than a genius move, I believe. 
Schizoid PD can be co-morbid with psychopathy, bipolar and, I believe schizophrenia. I still think someone who is schizoid with no other disorders is very unlikely to be murderously violent."

175936540,"Using the word calorie doesn‚Äôt indicate any understanding of the concept of a calorie. It‚Äôs a very vague measure of chemical energy released in exothermic reactions. A calorie is measure of heat that can be gain via molecular interactions. The are a lot of different molecules‚Ä¶ and many of them are not easily burned‚Ä¶ if burned at all. Sugar, fat, carbs, proteins‚Ä¶ is the burn order‚Ä¶ if you are leaning towards sweets and fried foods or those foods with high amounts of saturated fats‚Ä¶ you‚Äôre only burning the food that‚Äôs coming in‚Ä¶ you can‚Äôt lose weight that way. Another fun fact is that a Calorie(capital ‚Äòc‚Äô) is equal to 1000 regular calories‚Ä¶ have fun counting that‚Ä¶ you actually need 3 more zeros on the end of every stated Cal label."

174336925,"Clozapine is a drug with unique properties, and for some people, it is the best and may be almost a godsend. That said, it is one of the most dangerous medications in clinical use, and also has a troublesome side-effect profile. For most people, the main problem with clozapine is not the lethal agranulocytosis, but (a) the disruption of the swallowing reflex, leading to nocturnal drooling and problems swallowing certain foods, (b) weight gain and associated metabolic disorders like diabetes, and ¬© unwanted sedation. Maybe I missed something? In other words, it‚Äôs the best drug for some people, but for the majority it is not. Alas, you don‚Äôt know in advance to which category you belong. Personally, I agreed to try it in the hope of amelioration of negative symptoms, which alas did not materialise, and now I‚Äôm having trouble getting the doctors to switch me to another drug with a better side-effect profile, and I regret ever agreeing to a trial. -_NAME_."

174336932,"Hey flor1231, I no longer take a single dose of any benzodiazepines and have been off of them for over 3 years (aside from any of the odd occasions they had been given under a doctors order during an operation procedure or emergency room visit which happened less than 5 times that I can remember). I was prescribed both clonazepam and lorazepam from a young age starting at age 12 and then started withdrawing slowly under doc supervision by age 20 due to physical dependence that was developed by addictive qualities of the drugs themselves. Valium (often describes as a weaker short acting version of the two above mentioned benzodiazepines- commonly heard of brand names in North America are Klonopin or Ativan; despite being several times more addictive and more likely to onset rebound panic attacks [which are much more severe than generalized anxiety attacks and consist of more physical symptoms not limited to shaking and breathing or swallowing difficulties but will have been accompanied by communicat
ion impairment/appearance of serious neurological sudden onset symptoms and deficits which are typically seen as serious enough to wind up in emergency room visits over the severity which can appear to an average person as someone suffering a heart attack or stroke, whilst they are in the sudden change of their normal state or calmer state which the drugs provide for a little bit of time being drastically different and shocking to provoke unnecessary hospitalization induced by half life descending in time when compared from the moment a patient with anxiety takes the drug till the time it wares off and is expunged from their system vs. A patient with panic disorder and the time it was ingested to the lesser time it feels psychologically helpful for despite being roughly the same amount of time biologically to be entirely removed all traces of the drug in the body being the same] The result of a generalization of anxiety or a complex/childhood trauma panic disorder technically shouldn't carry the drug less tim
e in the system from the time of release but for whatever reason, studies have been showing that the more severe trauma or anxiety disorder being a sudden onset during adulthood during episodes when the patients are doing dialectical or cognitive therapy, they are more likely to need increases in doses, stronger drugs with long release form instead of short release form versions being necessary on top of more frequently needing the drug to stop their severe anxiety or panic from completely taking over functionality of the patients every day life. The downside to this is the increased chance of addiction and physical dependence of these drugs which wind up costing more and more hospitalizations in psychiatric or addiction institutions, as well as debt to patients who can't afford treatment in the first place for if/when these side effects to needing more strong pharmaceuticals or more of the same pharmaceuticals until the inevitable tolerance build up happens when taking drugs intended only for short term trea
tment of no more than 2 weeks-2 months for long acting benzodiazepines and 5 days- 4 months for short acting benzodiazepines being the recommended prescription refill length for the increase in addiction and dependency rates doubling exceeding above and beyond those periods of prescription length where a patient will have a good chance of getting off the drug and staying off the drug with no trouble in comparison to someone who has been prescribed benzodiazepines in multiple various brands for long periods of time. Here is my non health and science and pharmaceuticals geek form of advice for you, coming from someone who has borderline personality traits and a genetic disease that causes psychiatric symptoms to appear during young adolescence which makes the disease that much more difficult to diagnose and which caused me more difficulty in diagnosis of psychiatric symptoms correlating to typical characteristics of any easy to treat once discovered psychiatric disease (I.e. schizophrenia or bipolar disorder is 
treated with only so many options of drugs whereas borderline personality disorder is not treatable with drugs and not diagnosed below the legal adult age as per country or province states that all children are not capable of displaying personality disorders and unless they are a danger to themselves or others they must remain treated as if they don't have any personality disorder because they are dependent on their parents and guardians to provide them with the tools they need for life and if it isn't anti social behaviour, the parents are better for making a difference than medication or hospitalization would, which is the truth in every case except for anti-social personality disorder for that becomes sociopaths or worse as adults and that can only be prevented with help and treatment from specialized treatment depending on a much deeper understanding of the role a parent(s) plays in a child's' life). All of that being said- I only got diagnosed with traits which is a much less serious diagnosed borderline 
personality disorder at the age of 25 and then that helped me understand why medication had never worked for me for if my case file were a lot less complicated, in terms of no query _NAME_ disease no query autism spectrum female adult with adhd no query major depressive disorder/panic disorder/bipolar disorder query mother diagnosed genetic factors at play/etc. Basically been ""query"" diagnosed with everything except for schizophrenia despite a famililial history of it, no matter what I got written down on paper by a doctor in the USA where I grew up, to now living in Canada and having been analyzed by a total of 5 different psychiatric specialists here, none of the words on paper will change childhood trauma and neglect, to addiction and work in the sex trade resulting from severe under treated panic and anxiety which stemmed from not just childhood but life long repeated attempts at fixing the problem within only to be victim and preyed on by violent abusers in my life despite being in constant trial and e
rror in times of ""doing what should be done to avoid more trauma piled up on top of old unresolved trauma despite years of treatment since new trauma kept layering to undo any positive change in lieu of the time spent in cbt or dbt or 12 step or self help reading and workbook activities being incorporated into my daily life without fail. It took me a long time to figure out how meds such as benzodiazepines were more harmful than helpful when it truly worked and stopped my manifestation of panic in public, although I still can't identify the cause of my panic when in the moment, it comes over me less and less as time goes on but unfortunately fairly severe and long time from start to finish when they do occur from time to time, but I'm sure it's a heck of a lot better than dealing with the fear of day to day embarrassing situations running away from friends and coworkers to hide and hyperventilate or pass out from black/white noise blurred vision and dizziness for a half hour spent in my car or in the bathroo
m only to wind up in an er being stuck for over 6 hours with no one to help me out because I'm not actually dying and in the odd case that I had heart rhythm irregularities and did actually have a reason to grey out and cause panic were only a result of not taking the meds on a regular basis when it said take as needed for anxiety on the bottle up to 3x daily as prescribed by the doctor not take 3x daily as per directions from doctor or anything else that would have said don't fail and miss a dose because you'll regret it when your meds ware off and you're working till 10 pm with no spare pills in your purse! I have at most one time a year where I have a long two hour outburst of sheer panic with disabling physical symptoms, but it's always onset by the same thing... prolonged period of strength and stability that has been shaken by someone or something that was said in public during a group therapy of sorts or group meditation wellness excercise which unfortunately tends to harm people from success in recove
ry methods used commonly for dialectical ""talk"" behaviour therapy in cases of bpd and asd or any other non common co-occurring disorder where thinking reality has been in question because reality is fact and not easily shaken when it comes to most mentally ill or addiction suffered combinations of diagnosed people seeking help with treatment of their disease. Medication solves only 30% of the problem for common mental health issues (schizophrenia not included as per medication is much more likely to cause worsening symptoms of the disease if not taken as prescribed whereas the ladder is less likely affected with vs without medication long term care facilities and treatment teams etc. Are all considered before meds in those other cases when schizophrenia is not a diagnosed concern) and the other 70% is all dependent on psychosomatic wellness (I.e. social, psychological and behavioural related causes which are playing into the symptoms; Often times a prescriber will consider these 3 external and internal valu
es and consider a need for therapeutical value as a higher priority and success rate when treating young adults and adolescents with early onset psychiatric symptoms for a long time before even turning to any form of a medication beyond anti depressants for <1 year trial runs for short term treatment in severe cases before they continue prescribing anything else because of the strength in numbers of patients who do well with their mental health disorder and sustain long term recovery solely resulting from a correct cocktail of counselling, social/outward support and multiple means of healthcare access in form of one on one talk therapy, group therapy and psychologist or psychiatric treatment all going into the factor of psychosomatic therapy over medication as a last resort of unfollowed instructions or incorrectly diagnosed mental health disorders which systematically result in the wrong treatment plan being developed based on what would be best for the common sufferers of that particular disorder gaining st
rength in lieu of treatment that is not generally recognized as effective for people with common traits of xyz personality disorder (which does not happen often making it that much more problematic when it does occur because once you get diagnosed with one or many other different disorders or labels within a psychiatric community, doctors are less and less likely to shed light or question the query of diagnosis or disorder that led you to their office chair in the first place and rather than get to know who is in their chair, the flaw of the community is they get to know the pieces of paper that other doctors' in treating you along the way have written down about you no matter how old or different it is from what they see, it is not etiquette to question a doctor that is senior to you, and a fresh perspective of a young fresh out of school student resident doctor is great if they aren't worried about following the shoes they are filling in for as the more important part of the process in treating the person a
ttached to the paper). This last sentence heavily applied to my systematic mistreatment and distrust in psychiatric treatment in both the us and Canada but it did not stop me from utilizing the good coping skills I developed even when the program was targeted to the audience without my diagnosis and although harmful to my psyche in the moment and countless panic attack during, and after occurred stemming from the start of each dbt wellness group session and private session and self led session tried, for its what people with trauma best success in coping and derailment of anxiety long term would have been a huge benefit for me had tailored to the person fitting my diagnosed problem, it still was a lot more help than I am currently getting and for which skills made sense to develop and incorporate into my regimen, I still to this day find them helpful, although not trying to induce anxiety is more important because it disrupted other people from getting the help they were cut out for, and ultimately learning t
o respect the difference in my mind and health is the only way I can get my life in order so for that terrible year and a half I spent forcing myself to revisit trauma with every means available to me, it would be worth every anxiety attack I suffered through as a result because I wouldn't be as able to make sense of my struggle, I wouldn't be able to accept medication into my body knowing that it's doing absolutely nothing but at least it shows how hard I'm trying and not discounting my doctors opinion as if I knew better so that in turn I earn trust with my care team overall the old ways I displayed my need to change meds every single time something stopped working and insisted control over that based on all the research and reviews I read on gray web sites that blurred my own opinions about knowing my true self if it was truly something working or something based off anxiety it might not work and then fulfilling my feelings of control and urges over avoiding anxiety becoming more important to me than getti

174336951,"The use of statistics is not a problem, and there are scientific methods that don‚Äôt rely on statistics that are still used to study schizophrenia and other illnesses. To say that it has ‚Äúonly been verified statistically‚Äù shows a lack of understanding of the scientific method. Statistics are only there to show the likeliness that the particular effect shown under those particular circumstances it was shown in was entirely due to chance. It cannot ‚Äúverify‚Äù anything, only disconfirm it. Through repeated replication, that finding becomes likely, and repeated replication is the fundament of basically any claim you will read in a medical textbook that is presented with some certainty."

174336954,I was admitted 2 weeks ago for 2 days. A highly intelligent polish doctor and I decided to raise my geodon with 40 mg and raise my seroquel with 100 mg. At the same she decided to lower my Clopixol depo from 400 mg every 2. week to every 3 week. I received the injection last week and I haven‚Äôt had positive symptoms during that period. My personal experience is that the 1. gen antipsychotics manage the positive symptoms well. But at the same time I think that especially seroquel manage the positive symptoms just as well without worsening the negative. My conclusion is that the 2. gen antipsychotics are much more gentle side effect wise. And that they don‚Äôt worsen the negative in the same degree as the 1. gen antipsychotics.

175936820,"It has to do with the circadian rhythm.....we naturally get sleepy when it starts to get dark but most of us don‚Äôt see darkness in the same way we used to.....we have bright lights and screens that interfere with the circadian rhythm. The brain specifically responds to blue light for this rhythm. LEDs, cfls and lcd screens have a lot more blue light than an incandescent bulb and a book. Unfortunately it‚Äôs hard to get old style light bulbs and all screens have blue light. I use a three way light which is still the old style on the lowest setting in the bedroom. Normally we would get blue light from the sun only, older lights and candles are normally a softer light without blue peaks. A lot of people with bipolar are extraordinarily sensitive to blue light so theyve done studies with blue blockers, thus my advice. There are also special programs that shift out the blue on your screens to make everything look more orange.....can‚Äôt remember the name but google should help."

174336996,"Fully awake and fully asleep. This is how normal people go through the 24 hrs. When they awake from sleep they slowly go to fully awake mode and this continues till reach sleep time and at that time they get intense urge to sleep, no longer able to remain awake etc and they fall to sleep and awake next morning with no awareness of how night gone. This is how I used to sleep and remain during day before I had negative symptoms. I found over the years especially when negative symptoms appeared this ability to rapidly shift from fully awake to fully sleep reducing. At night no urge to sleep and need to force myself to go to bed otherwise I remain awake till morning. Same way when awake from sleep need to force myself to get out of bed otherwise it continue till noon. My conclusion from my case is I am not fully awake during day and this why unable to multitask, remain alert etc and only certain part of the brain is awake and rest of it still in sleep mode. In dreams also normal people not multitask or 
have other thoughts during dreaming and the reason is brain not fully awake and this lack of fully awake even during day time is the reason for cognitive issues and negative symptoms. So in my opinion to improve cognition and negative symptoms we need to emulate to normal mode that is to remain fully awake during day time and remain fully asleep during night sleep time. During day time we can use stimulants like caffeine beverages or others to remain alert. Several substances are there which promote wakefulness both in prescription category and in supplement category. Similarly take substances which gives deep restful sleep at night. These also include several in prescription and supplement category."

175936851,"If you look at it though, isn't that specifically a reflection of lack of motivation to do things you're not comfortable with (which you're not comfortable with because they're not naturally pleasant, unlike for most other people)? If you're the most reclusive person in the world as far as preference is concerned, but you still deal with the social interactions necessary to maintain a sustainable long-term way of life that suits you, then you're perfectly well-adjusted. The problem is having a pattern of personality that's so inflexible that it ends up being incompatible with itself in practice, and anhedonia/avolition is what seals that deal in SPD."

175936935,"If you follow this blog, you know that anxiety disorder has a high comorbidity rate with bipolar disorder. That means we live with both disorders at the same time. I have listed below some techniques I have used to get me through my moments of panic. Take a look and steal what you think will work for you. VISUALIZATION This is one of my favorite ways to self-soothe. Imagine your favorite place doing your favorite thing. Focus on your environment. Focus on what you are doing or not doing. For example, when I use this technique, I imagine I am at Mozart‚Äôs Coffee Shop in _NAME_, Texas. This place has an outdoor wooden multi-level deck with a giant tree coming out of it. To me, that is relaxing. I am sure you can think of your own place, or even imagine a place you would like to be. Read More Here: https://blogs.psychcentral.c
om/being-bipolar/2019/11/07/ways-to-self-soothe-bipolar-disorder-anxiety/"

174337019,"I‚Äôve ordered some from iherb.com I‚Äôll just post this interaction too. Moderate Interaction Be cautious with this combination ! Medications changed by the liver (Cytochrome P450 1A2 (CYP1A2) substrates) interacts with SULFORAPHANE Some medications are changed and broken down by the liver. Sulforaphane might decrease how quickly the liver breaks down some medications. Taking sulforaphane along with some medications that are changed by the liver might increase the effects and side effects of some medications. Before taking sulforaphane talk to your healthcare provider if you take any medications that are changed by the liver. Some medications that are changed by the liver include clozapine (Clozaril), cyclobenzaprine (Flexeril), fluvoxamine (Luvox), haloperidol (Haldol), imipramine (Tofranil), mexiletine (Mexitil), olanzapine (Zyprexa), pentazocine (Talwin), propranolol (Inderal), tacrine (Cognex), theophylline, zileuton (Zyflo), zolmitriptan (Zomig), and others."

174337029,"Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide is a cofactor that is central to metabolism. 174337036,"People who, later, were diagnosed with psychosis had a higher degree of functional connectivity in this particular part of the brain. In addition, the researchers also found that patients who have already been diagnosed with schizophrenia have the same kind of hyperconnectivity pattern. It is present among schizophrenia patients but not in patients with other psychiatric disorders. Hope they will use this to faster identify drugs that work by looking for this pattern before and after administering a new med. Seems like a better plan than reporting subjective symptoms."

175937216,"People don't understand me very often, though they do often know me well. There's a difference between knowing someone and truly understanding someone in my mind. Borderline personality disorder is a tough diagnosis. When it goes untreated the result is often very much what you're talking about. I've dated two people with the disorder and I've had and have friends that are diagnosed with it. It's a struggle for them and the people that are closest to them. That's the thing about personality disorders (and mental illness in general), it never just affects the person afflicted with it in isolation. I have diagnosed antisocial personality disorder, and while I sincerely do make an effort to avoid harming those closest to me, my condition still affects them and most definitely had an extremely adverse effect on anyone who knew me when I was younger and objectively out of control. You can't change who you fundamentally are, but you can choose how you play the cards you're dealt in life. No diagnosis has 
to dictate your choices or your life."

175937231,"First of all, understanding where the story began may give help to us. The Matrix Movies are based on esoteric and even philosophical \ religious ideas going back thousands of years ago into pre-history. Essentially, human beings, Homo Sapiens, have been on this planet, in relitivily the same anatomical state for at least 316,000 years according to all evidence from the fossil record. For at least 70,000 years of that history, human beings have left archeological and anthropological evidence of spiritual pursuits and rituals, having to do with life and death, the human condition, and understanding the cosmos and beyond. Additionally, there is evidence that other human civilizations have rose to power, maintained that position for a while, then went into decay and basically self destructed. Around 12,000 years ago, human beings after a well documented climatic event at the end of a climate cycle called the ‚ÄúYounger Dryas‚Äù started to build paleolithic structures, of which the earliest found (thus 
far) is located Gobli Tepi in modern day Turkey. These structures were built of stone and inscribed with in them are the symbols and beliefs and interactions of human culture with various consciousnesses, incarnated and discarnate, here and else where. These are indisputable facts and I am able to provide, in detail, evidence to these facts. As consciousnesses, incarnated in Homo Sapien bodies, seemingly we have no survivable intact memories of what came before our incarnation, or what our state of consciousness will be after the death of our bodies. I emphasis, ‚ÄòSeemingly‚Äô. Human beings have struggled with this dilemma for probably as long as we could be called homo sapiens, if not longer. Human beings have struggled to determine and extend the boundaries of inquiry, in a form of research and data collection, historically known as religion, modernly known as science. From the shamanistic, to classical forms of relgion and priesthood, into modern synchatic forms of New Age or New Thought, and into cutting 
edge physics. Along the way, one of the major pursuits, has revolved around fundamental questions, such as: Why is there suffering in the world? What is a ‚ÄòCorrect‚Äô view, a correct way to think about issues and situations, and what are correct actions we should take? These sorts of questions were most valiant in cultures surrounding and predating Zoroaster, Buddha, _NAME_, _NAME_, Socrates, Plato, ‚ÄòJesus‚Äô, _NAME_, and other such luminaries through the historical record (at least). They can also be found in seeming disparate places as the science fiction of _NAME_ and the horror novels and movies made from the works of _PERSON_, _NAME_ King, and in the fine arts of psychedelic artists such as _NAME_ Grey and _PERSON_ and all sorts of music, poems and dance, theater, film. The Matrix movies are relatively recent expression of a duality that human beings have psychically dealt with, probably since we first were forced out of the trees and onto the savanahs of Africa in climatic event, hundreds of thousan
ds of years ago. In any event, the Matrix movies are very Hollywood version of a very real philosophical and social dilemma of dualism. You will not find the answers in a movie. Only with awakened and enlightened perception and experience. Expect fierce resistance from people that you thought were your closest allies in life, those who would rather you be censored or be taken away than their world be upset or their power disrupted, but also expect guidance from those who have been maligned and rejected by the mainstream. The choice ultimately, is not the red (anti-psychotic) or blue (psychedelics) pill, or some sort of false dichotomy of that sort. Its a matter of the Heart and The Courage it takes to Live From It."

175937408,"I have a a SPD/NPD diagnosis, but from the outside, I'm not sure its much different than SPD really. The part that wants to be different is probably stronger than in classical SPD. 174337177,"I was just inspired to write this when reading the wikipedia article for _NAME_. As far as the jobs I worked I started work when I was 14 at my girlfriends request we got jobs at a local water park. I was a dishwasher in a fast food restaraunt. I worked most of the summer but when my girlfriend got caught stealing funds from the cotton candy tent and was fired I quit. Money didn‚Äôt mean much to me even then. My next job was at a bookstore cafe and I worked for a few weeks before quitting. The money wasn‚Äôt enough of an incentive to work and my attention span wasn‚Äôt up to it. Then I got a job as a dishwasher at a seafood restaraunt and worked a few months until quitting. Again having money in my pocket wasn‚Äôt enough of an incentive to work. I quit when they called me in on a day I was on ecstacy. I think the longest I worked in all my teens was three months. I wasn‚Äôt inspired at all by the work anywhere. I had friends who would put gas in my tank and all I needed was the money for a pack of 
cigarettes, spare change back then. I worked at a drug store in the mall for seven months but quit when they wouldn‚Äôt give me the day off to go to a concert. My girlfriend said she would go with another guy if I didn‚Äôt go so I quit. When I was 21 I qualified for disability with my diagnosis of schizoaffective disorder. I worked cleaning my dad‚Äôs office for a while and then got a job cleaning for the power company but it was six nights a week and I burnt out. Then when I was 24 I went to stay at a therapeutic farm community for people with mental illnesses. They didn‚Äôt pay you to work you just did and our families were paying for our stay there. I started on their forestry and grounds crew and worked cutting fire wood and harvesting maple sap for maple syrup. Then I worked on their garden crew growing crops for the kitchen. Everyone lived on the farm even the staff. They had a community dining hall where the food was great. I lived in a house called Mckee with other guys. There was a sauna house and a 
swimming hole that we built a huge dam across with rocks. I used to go snowshoeing at night with a headlamp once bringing a date. I then worked on their farm crew where I was the most interested I took care of cows and pigs, milked cows, learned to weld and fix machinery. I loved it. I worked hard and also did carpentry work. This is the hardest I‚Äôve ever worked and they weren‚Äôt even paying me to do it. I think that maybe the comraderie of the communal nature of the place was behind my liking the work. There was little to none of the preasure or criticism that comes with paid work. If I could live there the rest of my life I would. My friend Mark went back to college and got a job as the farming assasitant and does live there now. I envy him. There was never the loneliness or alienation I feel in my current suburban surroundings living with family in a place where I have few friends. I don‚Äôt know. I haven‚Äôt worked in years and the work I was doing I didn‚Äôt feel comfortable with. The mental health wo
rkers who come to my house every week ask occasionally if I want to look for work but I always say sometime later. I would rather volunteer. I miss that community of people. There were probably nearly 40 of us in our 20‚Äôs and 30‚Äôs. Always something to do and someone to hang out with. There was a music shack where I could get together and jam with other musicians. I miss the community there was there. Loved it. 174337178,"First of all, I don‚Äôt mean any side effects from medications. I have been tortured by my condition. I felt a REALLY BAD and STRONG feeling in my body (seemingly physical, worse than pain), which is like burning pain and restlessness combined. I call it intelligent because my Schizophrenia was intelligent enough to recognize those specific actions I wrote in bold, and when I‚Äôm doing those things - and then it would remove the torture. 175937828,"Opiates for treatment-resistant depression. ABSTRACT Aims: Until the 1950s opiates were often used in the treatment of depressive disorders (1). Because of the development of the tricyclic antidepressants, opiates fell into oblivion concerning this indication. However, only 2 of 3 depressive patients respond to newer antidepressants today, and even ECT achieves a remission-rate of only about 70%. Method: 3 patients (2f, 1m; 24, 39, 50y), suffering from major depression, were unresponsive to Tricyclics, SSRIs, Tranylcypromine, Venlafaxin and different combinations. Even ECT up to 14 treatment sessions remained unsuccessful. Subsequently, in an open label study patients were given Buprenorphine 0.8-2mg/d or Oxycodon 20mg/d as monotherapy. Results: In course of the opioid medication, within 1 week the HAMD-score decreased from 24.0 (range 19 to 28) before treatment to 4.3 (2 to 8) with opiate treatment, the BDI-score decreased from 27.3 (23 to 35) to 10.3 (9 to 12). Temporary appeared nausea, obstipat
ion and dysphoria. Conclusion: Opiates can be a hopeful option in treatment-resistant depression (TRD), even if ECT fails. Our results confirm former studies (2), but a new aspect is that in some cases of TRD opiates can be more effective than ECT. Perhaps, in these cases the endogenous opioid system is more impaired than the monoaminergic systems (3)."

175937871,"Easiest way for me to try to convey what I‚Äôm trying to convey: If I bake something, am I now a baker? If I draw something, am I now an artist? If I tell a truth, am I now truthful? If I tell a lie, am I now a liar? It is not possible to ‚Äòbe‚Äô all these things at once is it? We can only identify with those things and attach ourselves to them. But in reality they are only acts - and temporary ones. Sometimes it just serves us to identify with some label because it can be beneficial, but they have no ‚Äòfirm reality‚Äô on their own. I can identify with ‚Äòbeing a baker‚Äô because it would serve me to keep interest in learning baking and in doing the job well. Does that make sense?"
