175941062,"So _USER_ID_, have you been experimenting with your AP dose? I have been using zyprexa in the range 20-2,5mg, and I‚Äôm currently on 7,5mg. The difference between say 15 and 7,5 is huge. If I‚Äôm doing 15 I can‚Äôt work and struggle to find motivation to do anything at all. On 7,5 I am able to work and have a mediocre motivation. But it‚Äôs certainly a world of difference. Actually you need those to get motivation to do stuff, even if it can be scary to deal with them when you have been on a dose of ap‚Äôs that have killed them off for a long time. 175941264,"Thanks for posting everhopeful. The other article you just posted about IL-8 being a marker of non-responding SCZ got me thinking. It turns out IL-8 is a marker of aging too, aged people produce more IL-8 in response to infection. I think the article implies that if you can control inflammation you can slow down IL-8 production. This probably means an SCZ will respond to medication better (given the other IL-8/psychsis post) if they control inflammation. PubMed The effect of chronological age on the inflammatory response of human... The immune system undergoes profound age-related changes, including a gradual increase in the production and circulation of proinflammatory cytokines. Despite the known capacity of fibroblasts to produce cytokines, little is known so far about the..."

174338008,"What are the risks of taking turmeric? Side effects. Turmeric is generally safe. It can cause nausea and diarrhea , especially in high doses or after long-term use. It might also pose a risk of ulcers in high doses. As a topical treatment, it can cause skin irritation. Caution is advised when turmeric is taken by people known to have gallstones ; consult your health care provider first. Risks. Pregnant women should not use turmeric supplements . Talk to a doctor before using turmeric supplements regularly if you have any medical conditions, including gallbladder or kidney disease , bleeding disorders, diabetes , or immunity problems. Since turmeric can potentially increase bleeding, stop taking it at least two weeks before any surgery. Interactions. If you take any medicines regularly, talk to your doctor before you start using turmeric supplements . They could interact with medicines like aspirin , NSAID painkillers, statins , diabetes drugs, blood pressure medicines, and blood thinners . They mig
ht also interact with supplements that decrease clotting, like ginkgo, ginseng, and garlic."

174338014,"Would be nice if the research did allow for antipsychotic reduction in conjuction with sulforaphane, although this study from 2015 seems to indicate that only cognitive symptoms are affected. ncbi.nlm.nih.gov An Open Study of Sulforaphane-rich Broccoli Sprout Extract in Patients with Schizophrenia. A _PERSON_, _PERSON_, _PERSON_, _NAME_, _PERSON_, _PERSON_, _PERSON_, _PERSON_ and _PERSON_, Clinical psychopharmacology and neuroscience : the official scientific journal of the Korean College of Neuropsychopharmacology , Apr 30 2015 Schizophrenia is a mental disorder characterized by severe cognitive impairment. Accumulating evidence suggests a role for oxidative stress in the pathophysiology of schizophrenia. Sulforaphane (SFN) extracted from broccoli sprout is an agent with potent anti-oxidant and anti-inflammatory activity. In this study, we attempted to evaluate the effect of SFN on cognitive impairment in medicated patients with schizophrenia.We recruited a total of 10 outpatients with schizophren
ia, all of whom gave informed consent. Participants took 3 tablets of SFN, consisting of 30 mg of SFN-glucosinolate per day, for 8 weeks. Clinical symptoms using the Positive and Negative Syndrome Scale (PANSS) and cognitive function using the Japanese version of CogState battery were evaluated at the beginning of the study and at week 8.A total of 7 patients completed the trial. The mean score in the Accuracy component of the One Card Learning Task increased significantly after the trial. However, we detected no other significant changes in participants.This result suggests that SFN has the potential to improve cognitive function in patients with schizophrenia."

She says I shouldn't focus on pharmaceuticals and psychedelics because it can make my psychosis worse but try to do physics and math courses online and see how I do. She said that it's psychosis that lowers IQ and not the antipsychotics as much. She said psychedelics make the neurons connect to each other in a psychotic person which is similar to a forest fire of neurons and then it leaves holes in the collection of neurons that have formed in the wrong way.

175941414,"You don‚Äôt need any of them. Just like you don‚Äôt need any specific gene. Drug abuse is highly correlated with developing sz, but some studies show that there are shared genetic risk factors for both drug abuse and sz, and we have as of yet not been able to show actual population effects of changes in drug use on sz."

175941463,"I struggle to communicate verbally too. I often stutter and forget what the other person told me. Regardless, I write well, apparently. I was never medicated in my years of delusions. 174338072,"I think Rexulti causes less anxiety and less akathisia: ‚ÄúBrexpiprazole has more blocking and less stimulating activity at the dopamine receptors than its predecessor, aripiprazole, which may decrease its risk for agitation and restlessness. Specifically, where aripiprazole has an intrinsic activity or agonist effect at the D2 receptor of 60%+, brexpiprazole has an intrinsic activity at the same receptor of about 45%.‚Äù en.wikipedia.org Brexpiprazole Brexpiprazole, sold under the brand name Rexulti among others, is an atypical antipsychotic. It is a dopamine D2 receptor partial agonist and has been described as a ""serotonin‚Äìdopamine activity modulator"" (SDAM). The drug was approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) on July 10, 2015, for the treatment of schizophrenia, and as an adjunctive treatment for depression. It has been designed to provide improved efficacy and tolerability (e.g., less akathisia, restlessness and/or i The d..."

174338079,"Hi PT, I hope you are feeling well today Just a couple things to point out - antidepressants are not for BP - the induce mania and hypomania so as bipolars we shouldn't be on anything with antidepressant properties at all. Also can cause depression as you experienced with the Prozac. As for the Abilify restlessness is one of the main side effects. I had to stop it due to this and a lot of antipsychotics come with the same nasty side effects. I hope as you go up slowly it goes away. There is a ""cousin"" medication to Ability they came out with (I worked in psychiatry for almost 10 years and remember when it came out about 2.5 years ago..I can't remember what it's called at the moment!!) But the idea behind it was it has less side effects. Medicating is so tough. I am on Lamotrigine as well and I find it is one of the few that at least for me doesn't give me side effects. Hang in there, _PERSON_"

174338092,"ncbi.nlm.nih.gov Trial implementation of CIRCuiTS cognitive remediation therapy for people with schizophrenia in Orange, New South Wales. _NAME_ and _PERSON_, The Australian journal of rural health , Oct 2019 Many people with schizophrenia experience cognitive impairments and current practice guidelines recommend cognitive remediation therapy. This implementation trial examined aspects of feasibility, acceptability and outcomes of the computerised interactive remediation of cognition-interactive training for schizophrenia cognitive remediation therapy program in our local context.A longitudinal design was utilised with participants providing outcome data at commencement of the computerised interactive remediation of cognition-interactive training for schizophrenia program, completion and at follow-up 3 months later.Our trial was conducted in the inpatient and community mental health contexts within the New South Wales regional city of Orange, between January 2017 and December 2018.Fifty-three adult 
volunteers commenced the computerised interactive remediation of cognition-interactive training for schizophrenia program and participated in this trial. Forty-five participants were currently admitted to psychiatric rehabilitation inpatient units at Bloomfield hospital, and eight were referred by Orange Community Mental Health Service.Participants completed measures of cognitive functioning (repeatable battery for the assessment of neuropsychological status), functional independence (Adaptive Behaviour Assessment Scales 3) and Goal attainment scaling.Most participants reported they liked computerised interactive remediation of cognition-interactive training for schizophrenia therapy and made excellent progress towards their goals. Those who completed the program made significant gains in the domains of attention, memory and independence in key aspects of daily living. Gains in functional independence were sustained for a small sample following program completion.This implementation trial showed the computeri
sed interactive remediation of cognition-interactive training for schizophrenia cognitive remediation therapy program was feasible, acceptable and contributed to strong outcomes in both the inpatient and community contexts. Efforts are in progress to translate the computerised interactive remediation of cognition-interactive training for schizophrenia program, and future research will focus on longer term outcomes, cost-benefit analyses and the experiences of participants and therapists."

175941695,"You could always try to switch to another med and see if that works better. When I switched from risperidone to Geodon I dropped 40 lbs very quickly. Sz easily qualifies and you(depending on recent income) can recieve very good medical insurance(Medicaid). You‚Äôll be eligible for Medicare after two years, which will let you see any doctor without a referral, and you‚Äôll recieve a monthly amount that should be at least semi-efficient. You can deduct monthly expenses for your Food stamp application, and I believe housing vouchers as well. 175941714,"That seems normal. You chemically suppress dopamine. Brain tries to adjust to/counteract this change. I think by building more dopamine receptors, but im not entirely sure about the exact mechanism. Thus, when you quit or the dose works out, your levels of dopamine turn back to normal, but you have an extra sensitivity to dopamine because of the adjustments your brain made. Thus: rebound effect. Im not a doctor, but i think this is more or less how it works, in simplified form."

174338115,"Psychosis is a symptom not a illness. Psychosis NOS is usually diagnosed in people who are first experiencing psychosis in the absence of other symptoms. I was initially diagnosed with psychosis NOS in 2010 when I first told a psychiatrist I was hearing voices and seeing things. Schizophrenia is diagnosed after symptoms are ongoing usually a month or more. And other symptoms of schizophrenia are present like disorganized speech, and flat affect. I was diagnosed with schizophrenia in 2011."

175941795,"We live in challenging times for those with targeting delusions. When I first got ill around 1992, we didn‚Äôt have smart devices that listened to us and TVs that watched us back when we watched them. Now we do. Why is a Vizio TV so cheap? Because it‚Äôs collecting data on you and sending it back to Vizio, who sells it. That‚Äôs how they can afford to sell you a TV it costs them $700 to manufacture for $450. Are we being surveilled? Yeah, by big corporations. The best we can do is educate ourselves about it and turn off features whenever possible to mitigate the issue (plugging stuff into a power strip you turn off when things aren‚Äôt in use is a good start). Is there an issue? Sure. Is it the issue you think it is, that you‚Äôre personally being targeted for death or harm? Hell no. They just want to sell you stuff you don‚Äôt need."

174338129,"ncbi.nlm.nih.gov The clinical potentials of adjunctive fluvoxamine to clozapine treatment: a systematic review. _PERSON_ and _PERSON_, Psychopharmacology , Mar 2016 New clozapine optimization strategies are warranted, as some patients do not achieve sufficient response and experience various adverse effects. Fluvoxamine is a potent CYP1A2 inhibitor and may increase the ratio of clozapine to its primary metabolite N-desmethylclozapine (NDMC).This study aims to review all pharmacodynamic effects and the adverse effect profile of changing the clozapine/NDMC ratio with adjunctive fluvoxamine.MEDLINE, Embase, and the Cochrane Library were searched with the search terms ""clozapine"" and ""fluvoxamine"" without any time limit. Language was restricted to English, Scandinavian, Polish, and German. Studies were sorted for relevance based on title and abstract. Clinical recommendations of potential indications/effects were graded as level A, B, C, or D depending on studies of high, moderate, low, or very low 
quality, respectively.Based on data from 24 case reports/series, seven cohort studies, and two randomized controlled trials, 241 patients were studied. Evidence (A) supported that adjunctive fluvoxamine increased clozapine plasma levels. This may increase the probability of response in patients, where sufficient clozapine plasma levels cannot be achieved. Adjunctive fluvoxamine reduced metabolic adverse effects of clozapine (B) but not agranulocytosis risk (B). Although depressive or obsessive-compulsive symptoms may improve, a SSRI with no CYP1A2 inhibition should rather be used (C). No studies investigated the effect of adjunctive fluvoxamine to minimize clozapine rebound psychosis (D) or to reduce the effects of smoking on clozapine plasma levels (D).Adjunctive fluvoxamine may have clinical potentials for optimizing clozapine treatment but further clinical studies are warranted to explore the clinical implications. I hope to eventually go on clozapine and I‚Äôm going to ask for adjunctive fluvoxamine to at
tenuate side effects"

175941857,"The thing with chemicals.. There's no bad drug.. Especially if it's classified as a medicine. If they don't work - You have to find which one it is, stop that one with supervision.. It's a process.. One med for this, something for that.. There will be many new and better meds in the future - Some of which that used to be illegal.. Others will be analogues, derivatives, etc.. It's not the meds that have any effect in their chemical structure. It's all in the brain - The brain/mind is the experience of consciousness. Mental illness is a certain state of consciousness. There's probably hundreds of different types of depression - Maybe that's why some meds don't work for everyone. Since it's the brain that experiences, there's millions of people that are already on meds/drugs - naturally without even being on meds. It's like saying ""All drugs that get you high are bad for society"" just like ""All meds are bad for myself - Even if I have mental illness"". There's people that have been on meds and do w
ell without them because they never needed them in the first place but usually that's just a change of perspective - A massive change.. And it only works because of the anger associated with it.. It can jump start immediate coping mechanisms that haven't been triggered before. That's why psychedelics are being trialed for possibly treating mental health disorders - They cause immediate change."

Patients with contraindications to MRI scanning, such as dependence on benzodiazepine medica- tion, prohibitive claustrophobia, metallic implants or prosthetics, pacemakers, or any medical conditions that would constitute a safety risk to the participant (e.g., middle ear disorder), were also excluded. Broccoli Sprout Extract (Sulforaphane) The broccoli sprout extract used in this study is a highly stan- dardized formulation of sulforaphane [51, 52]. The extract was standardized to 100 ?mol sulforaphane in the form of 2 gel cap- sules per day over 7 consecutive days, as described previously [45, 53‚Äì58]. The dose of 100 ?mol 
sulforaphane and the 7-day treat- ment duration were determined empirically from previous studies, including a trial demonstrating induction of antioxidant enzymes in nasal lavage cells of human subjects [59] and improved excre- tion of air pollutants [56]. Our formulation of sulforaphane is 80% bioavailable [58], reaches peak plasma levels 1 h after oral ingestion, declines with first-order kinetics, and is actively excreted in urine (60% at 8 h) [58, 60]. 174338141,"ncbi.nlm.nih.gov Cannabis use and psychosis: a review of reviews. A _PERSON_, _PERSON_, _PERSON_, _PERSON_ Hall, _PERSON_, _PERSON_, _PERSON_, _PERSON_ and _PERSON_, European archives of psychiatry and clinical neuroscience , Sep 28 2019 We conducted a systematic review of _NAME_-analyses and systematic reviews to evaluate the impact of cannabis use on the onset and course of psychoses. Following a systematic literature search of five data bases (2005-2016) and consecutive structured evaluation, we were able to include 26 systematic reviews and _NAME_-analyses. The methodological quality of the included publications were in the range of high and poor. The scientific literature indicates that psychotic illness arises more frequently in cannabis users compared to non-users, cannabis use is associated with a dose-dependent risk of developing psychotic illness, and cannabis users have an earlier onset of psychotic illness compared to non-users. Cannabis use was also associated with increased relapse ra
tes, more hospitalizations and pronounced positive symptoms in psychotic patients. We make recommendations about the type of research that is required to better characterize the relationship between cannabis use and the development and outcomes of psychosis."

175941932,"I have constant social anxiety, that has never gone away. The good news is that you can learn to deal with it and overcome it. Now I‚Äôm so used to phone work that it doesn‚Äôt bother me to be on the phone and collect money from someone who is behind on payments, and those can be emotional calls. Identify your problem areas. 174338153,"ncbi.nlm.nih.gov Comparison of Clinical Characteristics Between the Patients with Schizophrenia on Clozapine Treatment with Those Taking Combination of Long-Acting Injectable and Oral Antipsychotics. A _PERSON_, _PERSON_ psikiyatri arsivi , Sep 2019 The primary aim of this study was to compare clinical characteristics between the patients with schizophrenia on clozapine treatment with those under combination of long-acting injectable and oral antipsychotics (combined treatment), and the secondary aim was to evaluate the impact of obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) comorbidity on the clinical variables.The patients with schizophrenia applied at Outpatient Psychiatry Clinic of the University between October 2017 and March 2018 taking clozapine or combined treatment were included in the study. The participants were administered Brief Psychiatric Rating Scale (BPRS), Clinical Global Impressions Scale, Scale for the Assessment of Positive and Negative Symptoms (SAPS/SANS), Calgary Depression Scale for 
Schizophrenia (CDSS), Yale-Brown Obsessive Compulsive Scale (YBOCS), Turkish version of Schedule for Assessing the three components of insight (SAI), and Global Assessment of Functioning Scale (GAF).Patients on clozapine had higher Y-BOCS, BPRS, SANS, CDSS scores, and lower GAF scores compared to those taking combined antipsychotics (p<0.05). OCD comorbidity rate was 13% in the combination therapy group and 36% in clozapine users. The SAPS scores were higher but CDSS scores were lower in clozapine users with the presence of OCD comorbidity (p<0.05).Clozapine and combined therapy groups differed widely by the clinical characteristics of the patients in this study. Both groups showed a high OCD comorbidity rate in this study and OCD comorbidity should be considered when schizophrenia treatment is initiated to obtain more satisfactory results. Furthermore, patients on clozapine seem to show a different relationship with OCD comorbidity compared to those under combined treatment."

174338165,"Dear Sir/_PERSON_, I would like to file a complaint on a news coverage about a person with schizophrenia whom has committed a murder. Please do not reveal my name if this email is released to the general public. After my arrival in my home country for recovery of my physical condition, I have relied on news from the BBC as a source of English news coverage. I disliked the _USER_ID_ against schizophrenia and the media companies in my home country that only covered stories of murders committed by people with schizophrenia. In my home country, having schizophrenia is often associated with lower social standings, shame, and rejection from their own family members, friends, and even parents. However, when I saw the news coverage on a murder committed by a person with schizophrenia on the BBC, I shivered in fear as I know that I cannot avoid the _USER_ID_ anywhere. Violence and schizophrenia is a very common misconception and myth related to this illness, and the rates of crimes committed by person with 
schizophrenia is significantly lower than the crimes committed by a normal person. Picking this story exclusively to identify schizophrenia as violence can bring very negative sentiments in the general public against schizophrenia, ?and the majority of people of schizophrenia have to continue living in fear, shame, and rejection from the general population. Please consider that people with schizophrenia are mostly not violent and these news coverage can deter a person with schizophrenia from accepting treatment because of the shame and dishonour they experience through the _USER_ID_ of the general public, mostly influenced by false perceptions of the media. I have been living with schizophrenia for 7 years and I have never committed a violent act. Due to the rising level of _USER_ID_ in my country, I have lived the past 3 years in pain, suffering, and shame due to the oppression. I sincerely ask you to not to oppress those with schizophrenia nor generate _USER_ID_ against schizophrenia by creating negative po

175941974,"ncbi.nlm.nih.gov Benefits of Gardening Activities for Cognitive Function According to Measurement of Brain Nerve Growth Factor Levels. _PERSON_ Park, _NAME_, _PERSON_ Park and _NAME_, International journal of environmental research and public health , 2019 03 02 The objective of this study was to determine the effects of gardening activities in senior individuals on brain nerve growth factors related to cognitive function. Forty-one senior individuals (age 76.6 ¬± 6.0 years) were recruited from the local community in Gwangjin-gu, Seoul, South Korea. A 20-min low-to-moderate intensity gardening activity intervention, making a vegetable garden, was performed by the subjects in a garden plot located on the Konkuk University (Seoul, South Korea) campus. The gardening involved six activities including cleaning a garden plot, digging, fertilizing, raking, planting/transplanting, and watering. To determine the effects of the gardening activities on brain nerve growth factors related to memory, blood sampl
es were drawn twice from each subject before and after the gardening activity by professional nurses. The levels of brain nerve growth factors, including brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF), vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) and platelet derived growth factor (PDGF), were analyzed. Levels of BDNF and PDGF were significantly increased after the gardening activity. This study revealed a potential benefit of gardening activities for cognitive function in senior individuals. Damn the vascular endothelial growth factor didn‚Äôt improve,"

175942028,"ncbi.nlm.nih.gov The quality of life of people with schizophrenia in Boulder, Colorado, and Bologna, Italy. _NAME_, _PERSON_, _PERSON_, C Bologna, A _PERSON_ and _PERSON_, Schizophrenia bulletin , 1998 The aim of the study was to compare the quality of life (QOL) and needs of people with schizophrenia in comprehensive treatment systems in two countries. One hundred people with schizophrenia and schizoaffective disorder were randomly selected from the caseload of a community mental health center in Boulder, Colorado, and 70 were similarly selected from public psychiatric treatment services in and around Bologna, Italy. Subjects were interviewed with QOL and needs assessment instruments and rated with the Brief Psychiatric Rating Scale. Objective QOL measures favored Bologna subjects over Boulder subjects, particularly with respect to employment, accommodation, and family life. In a factor analysis, objective QOL variables sorted separately from subjective satisfaction ratings, suggesting that they m
easure different underlying constructs. Patient needs in both Boulder and Bologna samples were primarily psychological and social rather than basic survival issues. Boulder subjects were more likely to report accommodation needs. Many apparent QOL advantages for Bologna subjects could be attributed to the greater frequency with which the Italian patients lived with family of origin. Living with family also appeared to confer practical benefits in meeting needs. Objective QOL measures discriminated between patient populations better than subjective ratings of satisfaction and well-being. Where would you rather live? Bologna, Italy Boulder, Colorado (USA) The Moon 0 voters"

175942032,"I'm taking 5 mg of rosuvastatin, and have for about 10 months. It's my third try at a statin and seems to be without side effects. Before that, I was on atorvastaton, then pravachol. Both gave me muscles aches and loss of energy. I decided to go low and slow to see if could tolerate this statin before increasing the dose. I started a weekly dose with 5 mg rosuvastatin, then gradually upped it to my current dose of 4x weekly. I tried five times weekly and had side effects, so backed it off. Some people do better with hydrophilic statins like rosuvastatin rather than lipophilic statins like atorvastatin. I didn't give up trying over the past two years, and am glad I finally found a statin that would work. There are non-statin cholesterol-lowering drugs, but they are expensive and insurance does not pay for them until statin options have failed."

175942042,"So I actually have an idea about this. You know how people that take drugs say it ‚Äúexpands their consciousness‚Äù? And what is their experience? Depending on how ‚Äúexpanded‚Äù their consciousness gets, it might be visual hallucinations, delusions running the gamut, etc. At the end, they go ‚Äúwell that was a weird trip‚Äù and maybe feel like they learned more about themselves. But there‚Äôs a Bell curve distribution for most human characteristics. Why not ‚Äúexpansiveness of consciousness‚Äù? It would stand to reason that there are some people out there whose day to day is a battle with their mind detaching from reality like they are on some form of drug. For those people, this battle to align themselves with the shared reality might be exhausting, much like it would totally suck for a random person to have to go to school/work while tripping on LSD day after day. So what if we gave this population drugs that ‚Äúrestricted‚Äù the consciousness to keep the fluctuations in how they experience real
ity more in line with whats actually occuring? The side effects of those drugs might be dulling experiences, just as the experience of ‚Äúconsciousness expanding‚Äù drugs is heightened sense of experiences, music, etc. And given that we know that lobotomies seemed to horribly damage that sense of identity and self, it is likely that our experience of consciousness is to some degree located in the frontal lobe. Basically, everyone likely has minor delusions (_PERSON_ as an example). But for people who experience reality the way other people would experience it on drugs, the ‚Äúrange‚Äù on those delusions gets way out of hand. Instead of simply thinking you are slightly better at basketball than you really are, you suddenly find yourself believing that _NAME_ Bird is afraid you‚Äôll end up ruining his record when you come into your prime and has hired people to take you out of the picture. I suspect part of the reason we don‚Äôt really have answers is that the very notion of consciousness is a bit of a taboo su
bject in academia. After discovering DNA, _NAME_ spent the rest of his career trying to search for it in the brain at the Salk Institute and, despite having a Nobel prize under his belt, ended up the butt of a joke among most scientists. Personally I agree with _PERSON_ that there‚Äôs nothing more important we could possibly be discovering about our brains than the nature of consciousness, but I understand the reluctance by the scientific community - it appears to be a puzzle so beyond our current level of knowledge as to seem futile. But that‚Äôs my personal theory on sz and the drugs to treat it."

175942088,"Hi, It sounds like you've had a really rough time, I'm so sorry. I too sometimes dwell on former friends who I was there for, not being there for me, it's hard to get past that. But we must, and the more that I think about life, the most constant thing about it is change. Your friends likely grew in a different direction than you, because they don't share your experience of depression and illness. I have lost many people dear to me because of that. They just can't understand what you or I experience daily, and probably truthfully can't bear to try. I have been there for a few friends who were depressed, and it took so much mental strength to cope with it, to be there for them. People who don't know depression or illness can't be there for you, they don't know how. It helps me to say these things that I know are true but that somehow, when I'm feeling hurt, I forget. I just feel the pain and betrayal. But saying it to you, I know the truth of it. If you and I can be at peace with that, then it opens 
up a way to move forward. I agree that I try to put on my happy face with people but it feels like an effort and it doesn't feel fulfilling. I want to talk about this heavy stuff that isn't really accepted in normal society, it's often the elephant in the room that I'm studiously avoiding. And yes, people make you feel like a nut for all of it. I went from being somewhat healthy and athletic to barely able to slowly walk a block, and even after I finally got a Lyme diagnosis, it was somehow still all in my head, and I was expected to continue caring for everyone just as if I was well. But yes, I believe you can make friends again and so can I. It all comes down in the end to not letting those lousy experiences cloud the way we see ourselves. I appreciate your reaching out to me and hope that I can be a support to you. Please believe in your goodness."
175942089,"I‚Äôm not talking about getting good at something, I am talking about these self proclaimed youtube artists that tell you how you can make yourself more intelligent or change your personality by watching a couple of 5 minute videos."

175942114,"I believe in the adrenochrome theory causing at least some positives. Anxiety will turn into adrenaline and that will create adrenochrome. en.m.wikipedia.org Adrenochrome Adrenochrome is a chemical compound with the molecular formula C9H9NO3 produced by the oxidation of adrenaline (epinephrine). The derivative carbazochrome is a hemostatic medication. Despite a similarity in chemical names, it is unrelated to chrome or chromium. In vivo, adrenochrome is synthesized by the oxidation of epinephrine. In vitro, silver oxide (Ag2O) is used as an oxidizing agent. Its presence is detected in solution by a pink color. The color turns brown upon polymerization. Sever... Read under effect on brain"

175942120,"ive been taking black seed oil on and off since the beginning of the year. havent taken it recently because i started zoloft and in my research i found black seed oil increases serotonin so they should probably not be combined. i was mainly interested in the mental effects of black seed oil but the physical is good too as it seems to effect alot of different parts of the body. a few things i know about it is its an hdac inhibitor which if you dont know what that is you can look on google about what those help with. it is also an AChEI, increases serotonin, also an antihistamine. it reduces opioid tolerance and has an effect on gaba as well. there are many studies done on it just search black seed oil and any of those receptors and youll see them one thing i notice from taking it is that it almost has an immediate effect from taking it, kind of hard to describe completely but you feel it in your eyes. you can tell which brands are more potent. i had good results with it tho i stopped with it at firs

174338213,"Modern schizophrenic delusions reflect the current technology and environment. I remember reading something that compared delusions from the old days before the onset of modern sci-fi fiction for example. Back in the 1900s the delusions were based on ghosts and spirits, 1950s onwards more CIA based etc. Schizophrenia remains the same but the context alters the delusion. The person is still delusional though as a trait, rather than being sz from social constructs per se. The sz reflects the environment."

At any rate, this thread was prompted by those questions that are either impossible to answer but remain humanly compelling, or haven‚Äôt been answered to general satisfaction."

175942237,"I‚Äôm not sure if this is the right board for this, apologies if it isn‚Äôt. And first off, I feel like I should put a trigger warning here for unreality and the discussion of subjective reality. So, I‚Äôm in college and taking a philosophy course, and one of our readings was about how maybe nothing is real except for what we perceive. This struck me as a psychotic person, because what if a lot of what I perceive is largely classified as ‚Äúnot real?‚Äù So I got to thinking about reality and how it must be subjective - the example I like to use is color; we know that everyone sees color differently, so even just based on that alone, everyone experiences reality slightly differently, and so must be subjective. If reality has to be subjective, why are my experiences classified as ‚Äúnot real?‚Äù I understand that the majority of people don‚Äôt experience hallucinations and ‚Äòdelusions‚Äô (I have complicated feelings about that word) like I do, and presumably like many people on this forum do, but so
metimes I feel like these experiences are discounted by virtue of being ‚Äúnot real,‚Äù which can be frustrating sometimes. However, on the other hand, sometimes I don‚Äôt like the idea that my hallucinations and the things I believe could be considered real - that‚Äôs kind of scary! So I‚Äôm torn between thinking psychotic experiences can, or even should, be considered ‚Äúreal,‚Äù and thinking that the dominant view of hallucinations and such being ‚Äúnot real‚Äù is helpful and for the best. Anyways, this got a bit longer than I was expecting it to, sorry. I just thought it was kind of an interesting topic, and I guess what I want to ask is, does anyone else have any opinions on this?"

174338236,"The most accurate test was based on the 10 most predictive proteins. It correctly identified those who would go on to develop a psychotic disorder in 93% of high-risk cases, and it correctly identified those who would not in 80% of cases. That‚Äôs pretty darn good. Of course as yet they have no way to prevent schizophrenia from developing in at risk people. There are some trials. But it also might help if they can start trials in at risk people before it becomes clear they‚Äôre at risk. But yeah, lots of groups have done something like this. It can also be frustrating to the person who revived the thread when they don‚Äôt get a reply, because the original poster is no longer active or no longer finds the topic relevant. ack in a car on the way home from another province with 2 kids and an adult with me. After this recent episode I didn't even want to get into my car the next day to go get milk 5 mins away. 175942449,"It can be really scary to first start medications. I think my biggest advice on it would be if you get horrible side effects on a med, even from several meds, don‚Äôt say oh all medication is terrible and won‚Äôt work for me, just know those meds weren‚Äôt for you. It can take a long time, YEARS, to find the perfect med for you that gives minimal to no side effects and manages your symptoms. But once you find those perfect meds, it is LIFE CHANGING. Seriously, you finally learn what it‚Äôs like to have a normal life and it‚Äôs like you dont have an illness anymore at all. No more suffering. 174338287,"Philadelphia, August 20, 2019 - Brain abnormalities in people at familial risk of schizophrenia and bipolar disorder emerge in unique patterns, despite the symptom and genetic overlap of the disorders, according to a study in Biological Psychiatry , published by Elsevier. Similarities between schizophrenia and bipolar disorder have led to the diagnoses being increasingly combined in studies of psychosis, but the findings highlight that risk for the disorders has distinct effects on the brain. https://www.eurekalert.org/pub_releases/2019-08/e-rop081919.php"

174338299,"I‚Äôve been on abilify for nearly 6 years. There‚Äôs some evidence that abilify doesn‚Äôt stop working unlike other meds. ncbi.nlm.nih.gov Aripiprazole may be free from tachyphylaxis: preliminary findings. _PERSON_, _PERSON_, _PERSON_ and _PERSON_, Psychiatry and clinical neurosciences , Mar 2012 Loss of antipsychotic efficacy (tachyphylaxis), possibly linked to an increase in D? receptor number and sensitivity, is a significant impediment to treatment in chronic schizophrenia patients. Animal studies, however, suggest that aripiprazole may be free from tachyphylaxis. The aim of the present study was to investigate this hypothesis. In this preliminary study, aripiprazole-treated patients were retrospectively investigated for the presence or absence of tachyphylaxis. Clinical Global Impression-Improvement (CGI-I) scores did not significantly change and there was no significant association of CGI scores with fixed dose duration. This suggests that aripiprazole may be free from tachyphylaxis."

175942762,"Anybody would be stressed out greatly after facing those issues. Especially the pet stuff. In fact, the pet stuff alone would be enough. Any negative changes in life always bring stress. All human brains get upset with that and try to turn away. Its a natural part of life and even more serious for sz brains cos I think we feel emotions stronger. Fear, depression, anxiety etc. I cope with my stress either by not trying to turn away when I experience stress. That is easy to speak of but hard to practice. But once you get better with practice, there are benefits like less upset during stress and greater appreciation of non-stressful time. The little things that make you happy are more noticeable then and they add up to make your life more enjoyable. Like the coffee you have early in the morning and the joy you get from finished chores. Deep breathing and regular meditation are also good stress relievers."

175942979,"Abstract Cognitive impairments in learning and memory are core symptoms of schizophrenia, associated with reduced self-reported quality of life. The most effective treatment of cognitive impairments is drill and practice cognitive training. Still, to date no study has investigated the effect of varying the frequency of training on cognitive outcomes. Here we utilized a verbal memory based language learning task, tapping into implicit cognitive processes, to investigate the role of training intensity on learning rates in individuals with schizophrenia. Data from 47 participants across two studies was utilized, one with a daily training regimen over 5 days and the other with a more intensive schedule of 5 sessions delivered over 2 days. The primary outcome measure was the change in implicit learning performance across five sessions, quantified with the Matthews Correlation Coefficient (MCC). Participants in the daily training group showed improved performance compared to the intensive group only at s
ession 4. This is the first study to show that implicit learning rates are influenced by training intensity, with daily sessions outperforming a more intensive regimen; a period of consolidation overnight may be necessary to optimize cognitive training for individuals with schizophrenia. https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-021-85686-5"

175943046,"It can be a hard addiction to break. It helps to find a less destructive replacement behavior. some people will hold an ice cube in their hand until it hurts, and that is a less dangerous form of self harm that can be used as a stepping stone while you learn healthier coping skills. Some people draw on their bodies with a marker. They make a pretty picture over the skin they wanted to cut, and then they can look at the picture and see that they created instead of destroying. Some people exercise intensely, to release endorphins. Do you think any of these coping skills could be an option for you? Cutting is especially dangerous right now because there is a shortage of antiseptic, so it will be harder to properly clean and disinfect the wound. You will be more likely to develop a MRSA infection, which can cause you to lose a limb, or even die."

174338444,"We cannot waiting a lighting year until the researcher discover that the things be called hallucinations is not a symptom of the schizophrenia condition,mental illness or genetic disease ,rather it is a whole psychological entity (s) in an absolute state , it expresses about non-human creature in nature In reality,the hallucination is the body structure and the nerve motor of the health condition that you call it the schizophrenia To understand the actual narrative plot that corresponding the realism of sz condition ; 1-Avoid viewing the sz as a hetrogenous mixture of symptoms OR that the sz is just the sum of the behavioral characteristics of the person 2-Symptoms content that related diagnostic material (positive,negative and cognitive ‚Ä¶) is merely a personal reactions that arise as a result of the effect of functional activity of hallucination on the perception data of sensory inputs and data concepts of higher mental processes of the human host 3-No being convinced that each symptom is indepe
ndent of the rest of the symptoms OR the symptoms do not work in a connected,united context 4-Not being convinced that there is a cause (organic,chemical,psychological or environmental ) for every single symptom 5- The conviction that there is ONE root that creats all the diagnostic symptoms 6-Considering the sz condition as a whole central condition,have an actual existence in the person‚Äôs nature,it has independence existential features that was suddenly embodied in the person‚Äôs nature at the youth age ,the person was not born with it ,and it is not rooted from defective chemical functions that were genetically directed or / was rooted from psychological functions that were under the influence of poor environmental or social conditions 7-Seeing the hallucination a conscious psychological health condition for non-human creature,it has living existential features similar to the psychological existence of the human being,it is characterized by many supernatural properties that are used to modify or disable 
the higher cognitive processes of the human host 8- The sz condition itself is never represented in the context /content of the diagnostic symptoms ,rather,the sz condition represented in the existential features of the things called hallucination 9-The most importantly ,the person does not feel the existence of the sz condition which represented in the things called hallucination As he feels the symptoms of the disease or illness -whatever the kind of both 10-the person feels the hallucination as a whole living person(s),who has the full ability to expresses about himself and the world of all things by linguistic methods and expressive movement,this is despite the absence of an organic body for this strange person(s) in the external environmental world 11-We mean by all that,in principle,the person feels the hallucination with a new mechanisms -likeness that make him feel the existence of his psychological self (self-awareness ),and in terms of details,the mechanisms of feeling hallucination is more advanced 
/developed than the mechanism of feeling the human psychological self !! 12-The researcher who will aware the nature of condition that drive a parasitic organism to parasitze (intrude) another ,he is the person closest to understand the real story of the sz condition"

174338450,"B oston-based biotech Karuna Therapeutics ( KRTX ) said Monday that a novel combination pill achieved the main goal of a mid-stage clinical trial by reducing the acute psychosis and related symptoms experienced by patients with schizophrenia. KarXT is an oral co-formulation of xanomeline, a muscarinic receptor agonist, and trospium, a muscarinic receptor antagonist, which acts through preferential stimulation of muscarinic receptors in the central nervous system. The experimental combination antipsychotic drug from Karuna Therapeutics did well in a mid-stage clinical trial, reducing acute psychosis in patients with schizophrenia. It also had a more profound impact on hallucinations and delusions, and on emotional and social withdrawal, than placebo. Antipsychotic medications have poor patient compliance issues, due largely to the unpleasant side effects they produce. Karuna‚Äôs drug, called KarXT , targets the muscarinic acetylcholine receptors in the brain ‚Äî a pathway that first was targeted by 
_NAME_ in the 1990s. _NAME_ nixed the drug, called xanomeline, because of the intense nausea, dizziness, and vomiting that patients experienced. Karuna also uses xanomeline, but it‚Äôs in combination with a second drug called tropsium that‚Äôs meant to mitigate the difficult side effects. 175943376,"I have ptsd. Actually a form of ptsd, but I know what you are talking about from the angle you're trying to see. Watch for triggers. Avoid them if you can. THEIRS, not yours. With me, and it is still this way sometimes, it feels like everyone else continues down the river of life saying ""come on, come on"". But, we are stuck on the bank somewhere saying, ""wait, please, wait!"" I'm sorry you and your family have undergone trauma. It can be traumatic in dealing with the aftermath. Try not to blame. Ask how they are first thing in the morning. Before the day begins. Then ask again an hour later. Then again and again and again. Getting the trust of someone dealing with trauma is hard. They have to know you see them as the center of the universe even for just a few moments a day. BE PATIENT. I capitalize because I know you already have been very patient. You might be yelling right now. ""I have been patient!"" Reset and be a new kind of patient. Then reset again the next day or whenever needed. Creep 
back into their trust s-l-o-w-l-y. It can seem like an eternity but remember you ARE the grown-up. And you CAN do it because there is no guide on parenting but you ended up pretty good at it I am guessing. And if you can make through what you have so far you can get through this. Show them confidence. Confidence is everything. Even confidence in the healing power of ""I'm sorry"". They need a ROCK and that's you. Showing them they can be the center of your universe for a moment and you're confident letting them be there. Well, there you go. My love, my support Crazing 8"

174338474,"Yeah, okay, we get it. You‚Äôve been ill since you were a kid. Tragic. But right now, you‚Äôre just making excuses. Because _NAME_, it‚Äôs schizophrenia. We all have it, and it progressed all throughout our lives, just like yours did (except, maybe, for those whose illnesses are drug or trauma induced). Yes, it‚Äôll take time, but if you keep telling yourself that your illness is so different, so much more severe, than mine or anyone else‚Äôs, then you‚Äôll hinder your own recovery. I don‚Äôt think you‚Äôre faking, I really don‚Äôt, but I do think you‚Äôre allowing yourself to wallow. The truth is that meds will help each of us to varying degrees, regardless of how long you‚Äôve been ill. There are people in hospitals who had their first psychotic break, and now nothing has been able to pull them back. There are people who were gravely ill for years, and then comes along 3mg of Vraylar and poof, they‚Äôre practically cured. I myself have never had a complete break because my mom has always been on 
top of my mental health. I‚Äôve gotten close, but never crossed that line, thanks to her and my grandpa. In theory, my meds should work perfectly, only they don‚Äôt. I still have hallucinations, albeit less vivid ones, all of the time, and I have delusional ideas and episodes. I have disorganized, formal thought disorder symptoms, and my cognitive symptoms are more prominent than my negative ones. There‚Äôs no formula for how each of us will respond meds, unfortunately. It‚Äôs just a roll of the dice. I‚Äôm not trying to be a bi tch, _NAME_. Perhaps if I am, then someone else can explain it in a gentler way. I‚Äôm just trying to be honest with you, because you need to understand the truth. You need to understand that sometimes, meds just aren‚Äôt enough. If you want your shot at a normal life, then you‚Äôre going to have to fight for it, and you‚Äôre going to have to fight harder than some others may have to. Yeah, it‚Äôs sh itty and it‚Äôs unfair, but that‚Äôs just the way it is, so you can either accept tha
t and fight your fight without comparing it to others‚Äô battles, or you can reject it, and wallow while you wait for an easier path that may never come."

174338516,"Since you not have positive symptoms for 9 years I think its better to lower the dose of anti psychotic to see if positive symptoms returning. Anti psychotic drugs carries various side effects like the ones you experiencing like increased blood sugar, qt prolongation (heart related one, some drugs are linked to it), motor issues similar to parkinson etc. Doctors usually not tell about this to patients as their goal is to reduce positive symptoms at all cost. Anti psychotic drugs are necessary if have positive symptoms and take it at the lowest dose which solve positive symptoms. Also various kind of anti psychotic drugs there and some have less side effect than others so you can ask doctor to change the type to see if it not causing blood sugar issues."

Examples of neuroplasticity include circuit and network changes that result from learning a new ability, environmental influences, practice, and psychological stress. 175943578,"I am asked when I make an ebook on Kindle Store if I own all the rights to this book, and I always say Yes, but that may be if you listed a collaborator who wrote some of it too, or possibly have gone thru another print on demand publishing house, and you are also selling it also thru them. It‚Äôs not really a rule or a law that I am aware of, but I have heard it questioned if you published your book thru a small press which gives you say, 50 books that you can sell, you‚Äôre really not supposed to pocket that money at any price you set, since the publisher wants a cut too. I‚Äôm not 100 percent sure, since I‚Äôve never gone thru a small press, and one reason I can never win any contests for my first print book, or get it sold at B.A.M. or Barnes and Noble, which doesn‚Äôt bother me too much, since I‚Äôd rather see it at an Independent bookstore anyway. and the site might say they protect your privacy, but places like Facebook still owns it, and then your identity can be retrieved to people like the police, or in our case, if you start a blog of your writing, it is considered published every time you post it, and in some cases, it can‚Äôt be published twice, especially for submission on an online theme contest of writers, or a submission for print journal, or contest. 175943598,"Some things I do to calm down are: Put an ice pack on the back of your head. This will cool down your brain and reduce activity in your limbic system, where emotions happen. Do a task with simple, clear steps. I like baking. I follow the recipe, and it‚Äôs easy enough that I don‚Äôt get frustrated, but it requires enough concentration that I don‚Äôt have room to think about other things. Cleaning also helps. Engage your five senses. This will remind you what is real and what isn‚Äôt. Listen to soothing music. Smell something pleasant, like an essential oil. Suck on a hard candy. Look at pictures of things you enjoy. Feel something with an interesting texture, like a piece of Velcro or a stress ball. Try to levitate something with your mind. You obviously won‚Äôt succeed, but it gets you to focus all of your attention on a single point outside your body, instead of on your thoughts. I like to use this on airplanes or in public places, because it doesn‚Äôt require you to move at all. It looks like yo
u‚Äôre just daydreaming to observers. Listen to a guided meditation recording Student Wellness Center ‚Äì 11 Jun 18 Guided Audio Recordings"

When you talking with someone over the phone or / to be in a direct mutual bilateral dialogue with some friends or even strangers It is not reasonable to describe the condition that you are talking with a voices or talking to a voices ! 175943721,"From what I have read and heard: Your shadow self is the parts of your personality, good and bad, that you avoid thinking about and feeling. Often this is for social reasons. I have a problem with standing up for myself, it used to be really bad. Often when someone did something unacceptable or hurtful around me, instead of fixing the problem, I saw confrontation as bad and kept quiet, not feeling my emotions. However, when I was on my own later, the feelings come back and I would rage for 15 minutes about what happened. You would say being confrontational is part of my shadow self. To get past it, you need to acknowledge that it exists, understand why you are avoiding it, then find a way to deal with it without ignoring it."

175943766,"The therapy would be tailored to the client depending on what phase of their illness they were in and each phase would have different goals. Phase 1 goal would be to have the person start to question their beliefs. This is the one I‚Äôm still formulating how to do of course. Perhaps stabilizing on medication, then would involve going over all the experiences the person had and showing them how they connect to the symptoms of psychosis. For example, if the person had believed the CIA was coming to get them because they had superpowers. We‚Äôd go over that and how the belief of having superpowers is an example of a grandiose delusion, that the CIA is after them is an example of paranoia, both classic in psychosis. We would then go over what those symptoms meant, like how grandiose delusions help protect from feelings of uselessness and insignificance and paranoid delusions were the brain explaining the strong fear the psychotic brain produces randomly. We‚Äôd develop alternative coping methods for th
ese things and work on changing some thought processes. There would be reading provided or if reading was difficult for the patient we‚Äôd go over in session stories about other people with psychosis who had very similar symptoms. It would be excellent if I could facilitate some kind of group where people with psychosis could connect and see similarities between their symptoms. Phase 2 goal is to get the person to come to accept their illness and to maintain treatment. We‚Äôd look at patterns of what happened before when quitting treatment. If possible we‚Äôd go over diary entries of the patient while ill or maybe even recordings so they could see what they were like off treatment. Knowing warning signs that illness was returning so that they could recognize whenever they went off meds that oh I do have an illness because I recognize it coming back. Phase 3 goal would be recovery and then maintenance of stability. Involves dealing with any symptoms on a day to day basis, tweaking meds when necessary, monitori
ng symptoms, etc."

Phenibut allows me to do that except it also increases my mood so.. I could be having the worst things happening to me and I'd still be happy.. So that makes me realize that overly positive people have flaws too.. They don't notice how bad things really are.. Nihilism is ok in small doses.. Then I think, should it vary in life? 174338574,"why it is so difficult to deal with sz as a real mental illness ? Because,there are mythological belief within the theoretical models related sz; until now,they deal with the things be called hallucinations as a part from the whole schizophrenia condition,which it means that the hallucination is a symptom released from the functional activity of sz condition In sums,they look at the hallucinations as a result of sz condition While in actual reality,the schizophrenia word is just a name without corresponding condition,and be used to naming a group of different symptoms -nothing else the symptoms are the personal impressions of any external observer -whatever they are while the things be called hallucinations is a real living psychological health condition for higher entity (s),and the schizophrenied person coexist with the hallucination all possible time of mindfulness,day by day to the end of lifetime Internally ,inside the time-place of conscious state of the person, he does not coexist with a con
dition be called schizophrenia ,rather, he coexist with / deal with the things be called hallucination which producing endless of vocal thoughts all time of waking ,therefore he has going under the impact of this coexistence which causing the change in his cognitive material concepts about the world of things which in turns is reflecting into his personal behavioral responses towards all daily life events that he coexists / interacts with them in his external environment The coexistence with the hallucination during the time of waking is the cause of any change /disorder or symptoms ,and this does not causing a secretion of An Abnormal Chemical substances in the brain at all ,but the actual impact on the chemical balance system will be appears in the increasing degree of amount of metabolism results which determined by the timing of the coexistence with the hallucination along the day hours !"
175943821,"Hi _AT_MENTION_ . Typically, we like to leave inactive threads alone and just start a new thread instead. This is different than how some forums are run, but we do it this way because it frequently upsets users to have old topics revived when they are no longer relevant. 175943827,"I don‚Äôt think my ability to cry is determined by which medication I take. When I‚Äôm doing bad, I hardly ever cry; I only remember one time when I knew I was losing it again. Throughout my life I‚Äôve had a predisposition to cry a lot. And when the almost inevitable onset occurred, I lost that ability, along with most emotions. Its very distressing when I can‚Äôt cry, because I then understand that something deleterious is happening to my mental health. However, when I‚Äôm under good conditions, my ability to cry is enlarged. And when we had to put down a pet, I cried for the first time since my prodromal phase. Crying is a very good sign for me, and within reason, I believe is beneficial to everyone."

175943836,"During the few years before my diagnosis I though all girls trying to hookup with me or that I am attracted to them are trying to infect me with HIV to kill me bcz I am holy, Jesus. I overcame that fear and got a gf. Next day I had protected sex I went to the Dr and did an HIV test. It was negative. After a year we had unprotected sex and I did another HIV test and it was negative. Then I was sure that my gf was poisoning my coffee or drugging me. I told her to not make my coffee, I made it. At the end psychosis won, I lost the fight by being sure that I am Jesus and tried killing myself to prove it. The same day I was diagnosed with NOS psychosis after telling the pdr that I am Jesus."
